Amazing game all around. Just do not join an official server. They start off great, no lag and lots of players but after people start building... The server begins to give you a 10 second lag spike every 20 minutes like clockwork. I had all 10 artifacts and was ready to fight the bosses with a couple allies when it started to get REALLY bad for me. I was ready to fight the boss but basically quit the server due to the lag spikes. I had so much invested... the kind of progress that you'd never imagine abandoning. But I literally had to. It's inexcusable and desceptive to new players. Join an unofficial vanilla server to start so you can get the true experience. Boosted rate servers are way too easy and they are everywhere. The true excitement of Ark comes from being vulnerable, at least at the start. You do not get that on boosted rate servers, everything is too easy and you miss out on the best part of Ark. The game is amazing, has it's bugs for sure. I didn't think I'd like it at all until it went free on the Epic Games store. When it went on sale on steam, I bought it with ALL the DLCs because epic is absolute garbage(i have some horror stories where my games become unplayable on epic and their customer service will send you to discord and steam and ark only to be sent back because it is a clear Epic Games issue). Great game but I almost feel that their server hosting is enough to make me quit out of principal... So much wasted time and effort. It's so desceptive.. Great at first then when you are committed is goes to crap.

So, the game is actually really nice survival game, looks great, has lots of things going on, solo play is very nice but challenging, takes some time before you get the hang of it and I am myself not even very advanced yet.

Multiplayer on the other hand is not very suitable for beginners. Don't go on PvP servers unless you are willing to get slaughtered, grieved and whatnot. You will need friends in order to survive. I has none  :(

Considering there is no mixed review option I go with not recommended unless you love true hardship and solo play it's pretty nice.

Let me tell you something, even if you like dinosaurs, survival games and pvp raiding; this probably isnt the game for you. 

Ark isnt a game for people who like games, Ark is a ungodly creation that beyond all reason, despite it's unforgiving mechanics, disgusting imbalance, repetitive LMB-spamming non-pvp combat, janky and heavily exploitable glitches, and dear god the unoptimized mess that is its everything; still has players willing to stay online 24/7 literally taking shifts, to ensure they can have the most fun on a PvP server.   

This game in its intended form -PvP on Official settings- is enough to make you renounce even looking at a monitor ever again, I cannot believe people play and enjoy the game without playing with unofficial server rates; You could spend upwards of 2 hours taming your first low level dinosaur with the most basic method, and literally over a day getting some of the higher ranked ones, breeding has players literally taking turns to look after a virtual dinosaur for about as much time as I'd imagine it would take a real one to mature.

Good god I hate this game, but that doesn't change the fact that I have a SSD specifically set up to hold only this dog shit game because I can't stop playing it. I don't know why, I acknowledge all of its flaws and loathe it for them, the players beg for changes, map revamps, their damn dinosaurs not to fall through the world when they spend 12 hours hatching them.

 I want out but it keeps dragging me in, you can raid people and make them eat t-rex poop, like whats a guy to do?
Send help, or ascendant blueprints.

(orignal Review)Great game, even bought it on console. the devs are doing a great job on keeping the game updated, you can tell this is a game the devs have put alot of work into and there doing awesome. the graphics are great its a must to play with a clan to get the most out of this game.

ARK would be a great game if it wasnt for the players. The game is based around the time you are able to play. This has to be continuous time with little to no breaks in between. The worst part about this game is the way players are in PvP. Nothing matters to others more than your misery. Doesnt matter that people would get 200x more loot by leaving dinos and some resources for people to continue playing with, they wipe everything you own and laugh cause "its PvP". Most of the time this is done offline while you have no ability to defend your base. The turrets in game only delay them breaking into your base, they just soak up your bullets and boom take your loot and kill your shit while your asleep. This wouldnt be bad if it didnt take 2-4 days to raise a dino and multiple hours to tame a dino. In order to get anywhere on a PvP server on ark you have to have people on 24/7 and have to build up with defenses and turrets within your first day or you get to start over because people destroyed everything of yours. The dinosaur AI is broken, half the time dinosaurs (like Rexs) will just flee from the player for no reason at all. There was a boss that could be glitched and killed with ease for months on end due to a simple hitbox issue. Meshing has been a thing since the game started and its STILL not fixed apparently. ARK is broken from the ground up, fully geared to those who are able to play all day and it punishes the people who want to pvp in this style of survival game who have things to do. 100% commitment to play for 0 reward unless you like being a troll it seems. Not to mention they constantly pump out unbalanced broken content, where you get to try it out for 2 hours, (about the time it takes you to get half the bloodpacks needed for the first new tame) and then they get to keep your money. so its not like you can try out their new stuff and not worry about them keeping your money when you realize the game is actually even more broken with each new DLC.

Honestly, I'm disappointed. For such a large game, it lacks a lot of things that I need from a game. A. So, thats messed up, not to mention if you fail that bossfight you lose everything, and have to redo hours of work. Thats just dying in general in this game, you die, your dino dies, you lose hours of work. Mods help, yes, but this game does not seem to be getting what people are asking for, optimization. I didn't even mention the bugs, so simply said, for the price of this game, don't buy it, I got it on sale, so I'm lucky, still disappointed in this game though.

As you spawn in and think "Wow, this is such a beautiful game. They have realistic-esc  graphics, dinosaurs you can tame and make your own, breeding out different lines with ultimate stat customization, top tier building options and editing for the perfect build, fun pvp and pve maps available at a single finger click, cool colored dinos to commemorate all the years festive events and a plethora of new worlds to explore and conquer with you and your newly found friends.", you will soon find that you have lost 2 years of your life.

This game will consume you and your soul.

Your dinos will definitely starve to death.

You will lose your base and it's entirety.

This game will give you trust issues.

Your "friends" will betray you and you will be cucked by those closest.

Care about yourself.

Care about that blade of grass that tickled the bottom of your foot that one dewy morning when you walked outside barefoot to go fetch the newspaper.

Spend time wiping yourself raw from other shit in your life that boned you too hard and left you aching in pain.

Just. Don't. Play. This. Game.

Fuck I miss 2015 ark so badly, when there wasnt really a meta, youd see people walking around on anything, I remember even fighting guys on mammoths while im on foot with longneck rifles with my friend, tranqing out dinos and yoinking saddles because it was hard to level up, red ascendant weapons, before the snow, before the swamp, redwood and all that, just a tropical island with a bunch of idiots left to do their own thing, pteradon dog fights, just TheIsland, 50 players just out to try and survive and have fun, not having discord bots to alert them when they were raided, and instead of everything being turret ridden walls, there were large wood barns with all sorts inside which you could break into without slaving over industrial forges, having an underwater cave base with like 5 turrets felt so fucking cool, your megladon stored in the water section, having those big dog fights in the air with pteras while the rest of your tribe battles below on anything from mammoths to trexs (im talking about 8v8 kind of size not the mass shitshow zerg wars) getting picked off your flyer and making those awesome parachute snipe plays, luring peoples tames, having tames lured, taming your first dino which was obviously a dilo and then losing them all to a high lvl wild trike instead of a lvl 326 Managarmr called [][][][][][], having those giant bob wars on the beach with that one guy on a lvl 26 raptor, making stupid sized characters, finding stupid sized characters, the game was still a  grind, but fuck it was so fun, and I have more experiences from that first map, TheIsland than I have in all my 3000, of course I have countless others on other maps, but non that were half as rage inducing, fun, sad, and epic because the game was so pure,  even the smallest of accomplishments felt so much more making the grind worth it.

I played small tribes for ages, got max lvl, tek, the lot, but it just wasnt the same, it felt hollow, this wasnt the game I bought and loved all those years ago, the game was a dinosaur game, a simple, primitive, dinosaur game where the end game was electricity, it was perfect in all the wrong and right ways. Its honestly such a shame that the people new to the game, or even experienced instead of experiencing the things mentioned before, are having a 326 mana bop their head, the game was brilliant because even a guy with a crossbow and pike was a threat to you and your primitive flak armour while riding your rex or ptera, and not the lvl 300+ mana, the "top dogs" would always fall, and new would rise, unlike now, servers and the game were constantly evolving while remaining the same, beautiful mess of a game every player that bought the DINOSAUR game back then loved.

Decided to right this long ass review because ark holds a special sweet yet sour place in my brain, just really saddens me new people buying the game cant experience that incredible game at its peak all those years ago, where people played for fun, not to slave for pixels

Review:

the game conceptually is amazing but the "Community" And player base is beyond the most toxic I've ever seen. NOBODY lets you actually play a game, every big tribe has the monopoly on a server and they will cheat (Usually ESP) and find you and offline wipe you. There's an abundance of cheaters and the devs show only apathy with dealing with it. 

The Developers show no interest in fixing their game, the servers are terrible and unoptimised with THE biggest D-sync issues and lag I've ever seen in a game, hit-reg is almost non-existent. 

The only other way you can enjoy this game is PVE servers but you just hit a point where it becomes pointless to play, no goal to work towards and it cuts a huge amount of content from the game, on the other hand there's PvP servers; they would be so much fun if people actually let you get a chance to play but like I said, ESP and baby-dick syndrome will drive this insecure community to wipe anyone who even tries to start up.

The biggest reason for the toxic community is IRL trading, which is where the big tribes gather materials and sell them to other players for money. People don't let anyone enjoy the game because it threatens their "Business" 

Truly THE most pathetic gaming community out there.

If you're playing the on the "Island" Map you're probably not going to enjoy yourself too much. The premise of this game has always excited me, however, when I had first started playing I was disappointed. From my perspective the map was relatively plain and seemingly relied on the concept of dinosaurs to carry it. Exploration was a moot point when everywhere I looked I said "Oh, more island, great."

That said, I decided to give the game another shot on a different map. I tried out "The Center" because it sounded the coolest to me and I admittedly had a lot of fun. I turned down the difficulty somewhat and increased expereince gain so that myself and the friend I had playing with me could get around to taming the cooler dinos and exploring the more interesting parts of the map without having to worry as much about getting eaten immediately. Without going into spoilers, 'The Center' is a great map. There's a lot to discover and it honestly renewed my perspective on the game.

With a new outlook everything else became a little more enjoyable as well. After spending a bit of time getting acclimated I can now say that I would recommend this game. But only so long as you have a considerable amount of patience and you avoid 'The Island' at all costs. AT ALL COSTS.

I would never recommend this to anyone because it's falling apart... Played past few days just fine, today it won't even launch it's updating and stuck at 28%. It's not the first time either(I don't live in the bush wifi is solid). It's a love it now and when you lose everything you've acquired in-game you hate it and wish you had never found this game to begin with. Got it on annv. sale 50% off, I would NEVER pay full price for this game. It's so awesome that you'll cry yourself to sleep wishing it would actually work... But as you'll find in many many other reviews it's a "ship is sinking, let's polish the railings" developer team. There are people who would work with them for free just to get this working well but somehow they can't keep up with the bugs. Anyways it's been about 30min now and it's now at 30%, yay! There's really not much to do while I wait for this update to actually finish except write negative reviews and search the web for why it's stuck and watch my fave shows on netflix, yup fave. Go ahead buy this game, I can confidently say you'll spend more time troubleshooting why it's not working then playing, but the upside is you'll learn so much about how everything works you may be the next apple, well maybe microsoft for sure, downside... it still wont fix this game.

Ark, truly is a great game. I love playing it. I hate waiting for hours to download every ridiculous tiny update. Every time it downloads it brings in over 50 gig of data for nothing. I have ZERO (0) none, no, not one, ZERO mods and this game takes up over 180 gig of hard drive space. These are by no means new issues. I only have a couple hours of gaming time available to me per day and these pointless updates eat it all up.  This is unacceptable. I have found the only solution online is to move the game away from the Steam directories and launch it outside of steam so it cannot update. I am going to do just that if this incessant download ever finishes. There is no reason for this to still be an issue. I will not, cannot recommend this game until this is remedied.
 
All that said, it is beautiful, deep, haunting, challenging, rewarding, and a great ride.

I think that the majority of people who dislike this game are, in my opinion, playing it "wrong." I've tried official PvP servers... and God, what a mess those were. I'm a fairly busy guy, and I cannot devote my life to defending my meager base from an army of 13 year olds and others with positively no lives who can somehow dedicate every 24-hour day to ruining my experience. Granted, if you have the time to devote to that style of play, I have no doubt it would be a transcendent experience. 

When I first started playing, I think the first 20 or 30 hours I played singleplayer. I definitely should have done more reading, but I legitimately had NO idea how to tame dinosaurs. I was playing caveman survivalist. It was crazy, building spears and little thatch huts, running away for my life from raptors, building fire when the sun went down and roasting the meat I had gathered during the daytime... It was fantastic. 

After that, I unlocked Ark's true potential in, what is in my opinion, the best way to play the game. A private server with friends. Don't like the gather or tame rate? Tweak it up a bit. Not enough to ruin the immersion, but enough so that you don't have to spend an entire Saturday meticulously watching over an egg. Exploring the world, building bases, taming dinosaurs, occasionally grieving together over the regrettable loss of said dinosaurs... It's great fun. And even if you want the true PvP experience, who's to say you can't do that on a private server with friends? Even if it's just two tribes of 3 or 4 people, you can still set up organized PvP events with dedicated separate bases and dinos, and then go back to enjoying the PvE experience. 

If you aren't sucked into the environment and all of its magical possibilities the first or second time you get on, I doubt you will be able to extract any real enjoyment out of the game. But I would highly recommend giving this game a try on a private server with friends. There are easy-to-use hosting services that will get this all set up for you with easy access to configuration files for ~$10 a month. Well worth the money, in my experience.

This game is amazing in my opinion. I have had tons of fun playing it with friends, and am going to keep playing for a lot longer. Me and my friends, we built a house boat on a raft, and one for dinosaur transportation. A friend accidently got all of our dinosaurs but one stuck in the water, where they were killed by a Therizinosaur because he didnt let them fight back. We drove out houseboat through the swamps by accident, but when we got to the other side, we found a great place to set up base and have been thriving ever since. I like things like that, and I have enjoyed this game the entire time. 
Edit: After playing much after this, we have relocated yet again to in between the Frigid Plains and Winter's Mouth. A good spot, good dinos and such, killed one of the bosses, and so forth.
Crystal Isles: After taking a break from The Island, we moved to the Crystal Isles, setting up a base on the Nile type river on the border of the desert. There is an Incredible amount of great and cool dinos there. Great spot. Also has a great amount of rare resources at easy access.
its good i like it

ARK: Survival Evolved. It's kind of like prehistoric Australia "The Game"... Not even 4 hours in. I'd already been eaten by some gigantic piranha looking thing, a Rex, blinded and eaten by Dilos, fallen to my death- running away from raptors, shredded by raptors, froze to death, starved. And had all my crud stomped on cause a stray arrow hit one of those massive long neck dinos.... Even the bugs nearly got me.

After just about headbutting my keyboard in frustration. I finally got a break. Found a nice quiet spot where, not EVERYTHING wanted to kill me. I got down a solid little base. Made some tames. Started to progress. Got my first Pterra. Then was promptly reminded that i'm playing ARK... An Alpha Raptor and two of his buddies decided to tear through my camp and all I had. With me and my new Pterra barely escaping alive.

I was devastated... All that progress. Practically all my new companions... Turned into Raptor dung, in seconds. I perched my barely alive new friend on the higest thing I could see. And mulled over wwhat I could do about this dumpsterfire situation I had once again found myself in.

I took my new friend to go find some more meat so she could heal up. Then we headed out to find a new location. Eventually, we came across a nice rocky spire. And Fiiiiinally. Finally. I didnt have to worry about too much else other than those aggressive looking birds.


If you like to go exploring a beautiful world full of mystery and terror lurking under every leaf and stone. You might just get lost in the world of ARK; Survival Evolved. I know I did. And I'm glad I got to play this game. It's quite fun. In a sadistic, tear your hair out kind of way.

(Original review on Jan 16th, 2016)

Well this game was great and a bit challenging to start and I greatly enjoyed it.. Up until this latest patch. The devs decided it would be a great idea to take the main aspect of this game (taming and raising dinosaurs to fight for and serve you) and nerf them into a pointless existance. Don't even bother taming a dinosaur in this game at this point unless it is for transporation or to help gather. The hours you spent doing that could be better spent on grinding materials to make firearms to kill the other dinosaurs. Nothing like seeing hours of work poured into a game to tame and raise a dinosaur, level it up to level 150 only to watch a level 50 wild dino kill it.

Thanks for ruining the game Devs. Our community had planned on a pvp day and now that's in shambles until you fix this game you have ruined and broken. If we're going to run around with guns to shoot at people I guess we might as well go play CoD or something.

*****************
UPDATE (Feb 22nd, 2018)

So I've given it over a year since my last review of this game. A couple of expansion DLC's have launched and I thought I'd give the game another shot. I had originally loved it so much before the infamous dino nerf that had the community in an uproar for making the dinos next to useless for several weeks before WildCard dialed back on the nerf bat.

I am left sitting here puzzled at the performance on this game. Just a couple weeks prior to my first review of this game I had installed a GTX 970 in my 6 and a half year old pc. The game ran great. I could put it at near maxed out settings and it was beautiful without a stutter, easily cruising along at 60+ FPS. Now I have a much more robust computer with a more powerful processor and a GTX 1070 and the game runs WORSE!?!?!  This sent me to immediately see if anyone else had been saying anything else about it. So now I have to sit here and call BS on WildCard's claims of optimization. You claim to be optimizing this game yet it runs worse than it did a year ago. I understand you have added more content, but you have released a horribly optimized game. That's if your claims to have optimized, and continuing to optimize, the game can be believed.

When you can only run medium settings on a game with a higher end graphics card something is wrong. Sorry, while I see you have fixed the problem with the once overly nerfed tamed dinos I still cannot give a thumbs up on this game.

9/14/2020 Review Update

So here I am again checking to see the current state of ARK. There have definitely been some improvements and quite a few creatures have been added to the game. There are some interesting creatures in some of the DLC's and it can be a beautiful game. However I feel that the price of a now 5 year old game going up from what it was after initial release is a bit.. foolish.  The Devs are now asking more for this game than it was at release and, yes while they have added a bit to the game, it still feels like a money grab to me. Optimization is still so so, but the 2060 Super I'm using now seems to be handling it mostly okay.  It's a good game but if I were you I'd wait for a sale.

Gave this game a chance a couple of times now. There just isnt enough to captivate me to keep going. I have built a tatch house, killed a couple birds, made a hatchet and clothes and find myself wondering wtf is the point. There is absolutely no direction, objective or overall mission to accomplish besides experiencing the world and not dying. 

single-player is meaningless as the most fun you will have in this game is interacting with tribes and other persons which requires expansions and experience. Without experience multiplayer is basically a face-palm, my first hour in multiplayer was spent trying to find a spot on the map that wasn't already claimed just so i could build a campfire. As soon as I found a spot I was immediately nuked by a flying dino bird causing me to lose my items and respawn back where i started from. 

Yes the graphics are great, but the feeling the visuals give you will only last a couple hours. I wish I had not expected much going into this, this is a game that is closer to minecraft rather than Turok or The Isle. 

for those that want to actually enjoy a free-roaming dino-themed game, where there is a beginning and end with some point to it with even a little narrative, this game is not for you.

In my honest opinion, only hardcore Ark fanboys can recommend this game.

PRO-I enjoy this game, I play single player and it's a fun little sandbox with dinosaurs.
PRO-It's a fairly engaging experience and you may have fun building up if you can ignore or get around CONs 1-3.

CON-1. Holy #$%^ this game is a huge waste of time, literally.  Takes a long time to get anywhere.  Requires hauling lots of resources back and forth to build a base.  Taming one creature and take days just for the actual process, not including gathering the resources for it.  This seems to be preferred by some people that think wasting time makes the achievement more meaningful.  Not much of a problem if you jack up rates on a private server, so not a problem for me.

CON-2. The building system is ridiciously bad.  Hard to make structures even look even and hard to make contraptions that work due to restrictions designed for pvp; but you can somewhat alleivate this by installing CON-3

CON-3.  You have to download a #$%^load of mods to improve on all the flaws in the game.  Or at least a couple if you don't want to experience extreme frustration with the building system, among other things.

CON-YOU-SHOULDN'T-GET-THIS-GAME-FOR-PC.  Really the only reason I would NOT recommend this game, and it doesn't even have anything to do with gameplay.  People that claim requirements for this game are not high are full of #$%^.  Every major update requires 100+ GB of free HD space to install.  Seriously, you're expected to keep how many movies worth of space open just to play ONE GAME?  A lot of people had to uninstall more than a couple of games to update this ONE GAME.  And of course you can't play it online of Steam unless you update it, so, there you go.

Enjoy wasting 100 GB of HD space or headaches everytime a major update comes along.  This is why I believe only major fanboys could defend this game, since they don't even consider the above a thing; and I could understand that if you only play Ark all day.  I don't have a potato PC, I have other games I want to play.

Update:  They also regularly update the game with 100 MB ~ 2GB patches; and I found out that a portion of the community endorses this, because they like their "hotfixes".  So, if you like regular updates vs. their biweekly 20 GB updates on console, I guess this game is for you.

CON-5 for 2020.  Should have included this from the start.  DEVS ARE DISHONEST.  They make promises and don't keep them.  On the "first" season pass announced, it was for all future content.  Fast forward, surprise, every new content is a new season.  On the aberration announce, they promised some amazing reaper queen ability.  On release, SURPRISE, the ability was changed.  I believe the original promise was that you'd be able to tame a queen, but I honestly can't remember anymore.  They make empty promises, then will go back on that promise, and EDIT their previous announcement to match what they actually give you.  Everyone that followed this game from the start knows this.  No one even bothers to talk about it anymore.  Every so often you will have discussions pop up when they release something that wasn't what they promised.  Apparently, those promises weren't made when you go back to check the announcement =3

i've played 109 hours of this game - i've never been able to get further in than the beach, because RNG makes it so i get murdered by things that shouldn't even be there. There hypothetically is a difficulty curve, but there's also random spikes in difficulty, because beasts you aren't prepared for wander into your safe zone - you can try to prepare, but you'll get screwed over by something you literally can't hope to deal with. That's just...not fun. Even darksouls doesn't have the risk of the final boss wandering into the beginning of the game

This game is incredibly tedious to play in single player, and good luck getting anyone to play with you in multiplayer, unless you already know someone who has the game.

Its also incredibly non-immersive, because the game is almost impossible to play without the wiki, and even if you did manage to play without the wiki, well, the constantly loading and unloading textures will certainly break your immersion.Also, things load and reload oddly - because apparently if you play single player for short periods of time it just....seems to delete animals. And i have a fairly beefy gaming computer, and it still does this. Not to mention, the file size. Good lord this game took up like half of my available space on my hard drive. Did i mention i had to download it twice, because the first time, the executable for the game just randomly deleted itself? all the other files were there, the executable just vanished. 

I got this game on sale for 12$, and have logged 109 hours, and i do not feel that i have gotten my money's worth in fun. The only saving grace is you can adjust the settings to make the game as easy as you want, but to me i find a weird moral dilemma between wanting to, you know, have fun playing the game i bought, and not wanting to skew the game balance terribly in my favour so as to feel cheaty. Because yeah i'm sure i could finish the game pretty quickly if i made the settings favour my character and creatures while weakening  the things trying to kill me, but if you make it that easy, what's the point? 

I suppose whether this game is fun depends on your stance on PVP, how many willing friends you have, and how daring you are. Either you'll like this game, or you won't, in my opinion.

Review is of the Mac/Linux version! If you are of the PC people, this review does not apply to your version of the game.

TL;DR: If WildCard isn't going to update the Mac/Linux games alongside the PC game, stop calling it a cross-platformer or stop selling the game as multiplayer on those platforms. It's impossible to play alongside my friends, and the game sucks for solo newbies despite being a beautiful game with a lot of potential. Mac/Linus people, be aware if you buy the game you probably won't be playing it alongside your pc friends.

I bought this game because my gf has more than 5000 hours on the game, and it's been a fun part of her life. She's passionate about it; she talks about breeding dinos, meeting people in rp servers and making lifelong friends, and laying waste to her enemies in pvp.  So, of course I wanted to join her to see and experience her passion and what makes the game so great. Hey, if I can watch her be a warrior queen while I am over here stealing dodos and gathering thatch with a hatchet, it's a win-win. 

When we saw Ark available for Mac (she has pc, I have mac), we were both excited to play. She moved in with me, and we were waiting for her pc to arrive, so we couldn't play together. But I went ahead to try and figure out parts of the game so I wouldn't be a total newb (disclaimer: I am still painfully newbie and all of my ARK knowledge has come from my gf, please don't think I understand half of what happens).

For a while, I had to play singleplayer. 
 
Singleplayer is not fun. It is hard. It is punishing. It is lonely. As a new player, I have little idea on what to do or how to do things with dinos; I had to constantly ask for help in singleplayer mode,  which isn't a feasible game solution. My gf was playing her own games via phone, and I felt dumb for not knowing what to do. Most games give a tutorial. Ark... does not. I put all my skill points into oxygen until my GF saw what I was doing. Apparently hatchets work on stones for gathering items as well as pickaxes. And your character gets drunk when eating blackberries. Needless to say, despite being the dodo queen and capturing all dodos I ran across, I was not having fun. You can only hug so many dodos before you need the voice of another person to keep you sane, no matter the HD quality or map size. Art-wise, Ark is amazing- the water, the dino varieties (pls big Bront dino no step on my base), the scale of the land- the game is breathtakingly beautiful, and the art department did wonders. I just don't want to cry into my dodo flock in HD, when I could be crying with my dodo flock in HD [i] with my friends [/i].

However. Ark was meant to be a multiplayer game. This is clear from the ingrams/engrams/wristgem magic/blueprints that appear each level up, which includes cages, handcuffs, billboard signs. There's a push to talk key command. The game talks about tribes, and given that some dinos take *8 hours* to tame, a team effort seems needed. This is a cool feature; I enjoy games where the group must work together to build something greater. I was excited to be a part of that. Also, if you're in a group, you can ask questions like, "how do I find fiber" and "Should I put this skill point in weight or oxygen?"  or even "The hell are these prehistoric seagulls stealing my raw meat for?" It's even more effective in multiplayer to ask these questions because Ark doesn't have a tutorial to help you, so when you ask, your teammates are likely to respond, rather than your questions float away on the wind.

When GF's computer arrived, GF and I bought an unofficial server to 1) try and play together and 2) invite friends to play. Well, I couldn't connect. She connected fine. Our friends connected fine. "What patch are you?" 

Turns out, if you have a Mac or Linux (we discovered), your patch will be arriving... whenever Wildcard feels like bestowing it unto us. Until then, if your server is updated, or your friends game is updated, you cannot play with them. For some reason, Wildcard does not release the Mac/Linux version alongside the PC version, despite the [i] hundreds of other publishers that do so. [/i]

Should then Wildcard reach down their hands to bestow their god-like bounty of patch updates to us pleebs, we can join servers with the PC master race. But as soon as the next patch comes out for the  PC/PS4/??? (I don't believe anything updates before the PC game), the Mac/Linux people will be unable to be on a server (some official, all unofficial). The patches don't talk to each other; you cannot have a user of an older patch communicate with a user of a newer patch (unlike an MMO). 

Other Mac/Linux users who have passed through the golden gate into servers before the patch can no longer get into servers after a new patch, as the servers almost all run pc versions of the game. The users report (well, their friends do, they can't access the game) their dinos dying, their structures decayed, their crops fallow. Reportedly, people spend hours/days/weeks on the game only to lose all progress because Wildcard does not release cross-platform patches together. 

Two ways to fix this. The first way to fix this is to have everyone in the server turn off their updates, but that then means no one else can play on other servers because they now have the issue you just had. You're asking your friends to come join you and share the patch sterility plague. The second way? Wildcard releases all platform patches together.

Since neither option will happen (for me, maybe you have some awesome friends, review reader), I'll find another game to play with friends. Sadly, my gf and I will not play together on something she loves. I wish there was another game like this, but at least the other games allow me to play side by side with her, rather than talking awkwardly in discord about a solo run in which my dodos crap over my unconscious, blackberry drunken body.

There are other glitches: steam overlay doesn't work, my mouse also didn't ever want to work in game (it's ok though because I never know what I should press or skills I should give myself so I just didn't). Most of this game is glitches, according to gf, so my main point a complaint that this game claims multiplayer when it should not claim such on other platforms.

I spent 49.99 for a multiplayer game that does not allow multiplayer (because of how the devs release patches). I cannot recommend the mac/linux version to anyone who wants to play multiplayer.

Phenomenal despite all the bugs, of which there are many, but most have a workaround or are just funny (e.g. floating dinosaurs and eggs falling through the ceiling), so it doesn't really bother me much. My friends and I played on a private server, so we had to do everything ourselves, which was fun. The social aspects helped it be fun, but single player has some tools to help you solo things (I think like a 3x multiplier to some stats?). There are some "survival game" aspects I found tedious, like feeding large amounts of dinosaurs and watching babies with long maturation times, but the game provides sliders so you can trivialize those things if you want to. You can even make your tamed dinos consume no food at all. We didn't do that because my friends enjoyed those aspects of the game, and they willingly let me refrain from helping with those instead. They also find other things tedious that I enjoy, so it's kind of a neat team effort thing where we all can do what we like and others feel like you're doing them a favor lol. Each dinosaur has at least one unique ability or feature, so while some things become obsolete by mid- to late-game, most species remain useful, even if just for niche purposes. For example, there's a clearly "best" flying mount with all-around amazing stats compared to the others, but it still can't sprint short distances as fast as an early-game flying mount (which is also small, and thus great for just flying around your base without getting in the way of things). I think that's clever design.

One thing, though: I strongly recommend playing on a server with the mod "Structures Plus" (S+) enabled. It's almost mandatory. Building structures is VERY wonky without it to the point of being annoying. It's still a little wonky WITH S+, but you get used to it and learn "tricks" to make it do what you want, so it's not annoying 98% of the time.

I preface this review with a very high awareness of the flaws and bugs of this game.

My wife and I are always looking for new games to play and we seem to gravitate toward survival/crafting games with a sense of combat. The "survival builder" game genre has a lot of choices these days but none of them seem to scratch the itch quite like ARK.

I can articulate the pros and cons of the game and apply loads of logic to why it's good or bad, but the honest indicator is whether we continue to play the game despite the flaws. We do and here's why:

- The combination of combat, danger, mortality combined with resource gathering, crafting, building, and animal taming/breeding is a specific flavor and formula that I haven't been able to find anywhere else
- It provides my family and I the opportunity to work together when hunting dinosaurs or navigating through a cave but also the freedom to do your own thing when you've died for the 5th time due to miscommunication
- The ongoing progress and constant hunt for the better base location and build gives us excitement enough to talk about it randomly throughout the day
- It's a great connection with my wife that ticks a box for me that I otherwise can't get very easily

Granted, there are a truck load of issues that we complain about regularly. The long load times, the bugs, the map glitches... and of course the absolutely ridiculous inefficiency with disk storage are valid reasons to avoid the game... but I tolerate it because I genuinely enjoy the game so much when it's working properly.

We utilize the Ark Server Manager, as most do, which really makes hosting a server possible. It's the only way to fly. Unfortunately, starting the server can take up to 15 minutes in my experience. I've read stories of longer start times on some forums. This really puts a damper when we already have limited time to play evening games. With a little planning and server automation, we make it work.

All in all we really enjoy this game and would recommend it to anyone looking for that particular itch. The biggest caveat is that you have to be willing to accept the risk of some buggy behavior from time to time.

This is a game that has been around for a hot minute at this point in time. I have always heard a lot about it and several of my friends convinced me to finally get it. 

When you first start out, the game can be extremely overwhelming. There's not a super clear direction in what you need to be doing or anything, even though there is somewhat of a story/lore behind the game. 
How,ever after looking some stuff up online, and playing to get some things done....I quickly found that I could spend loads of time in this game!

The creatures are amazing and the world is very well lived in! Most of the animals you can tame have a good "job" function such as stone collecting or wood collecting or even just carrying heavy loads across long distances. 

I do have a few gripes with the game that I feel I need to address here. 

For starters multiplayer is kind of broken. Often times my friends and I are trying to connect to our host server and often get pushed back to the main menu, stuck in a loading screen, or the game straight up crashes. After several attempts we can usually get in, but again this is a problem.

Another issue I have is, the graphics of this game seem a bit dated. I mean I know it released years ago but even for its time of release games like this looked loads better. Even when you turn your graphics settings all the way up to epic...it never feels like the textures get anymore detailed. 

Overall, ARK's base game is loads of fun, especially with friends! My friends like catching creatures and I love building awesome bases so it works out great! 

7.5/10!

The one thing that sets Ark: Survival Evolved apart from both open-world games and role-playing games is that it is both. It is a nice balance between a role-playing game where the objectives and progression are clear and linear and an open-world game that does not have a defined progression. In ark, the story is told through your own adventuring. The progression is there, but not forced. The game even has an ending for those that want to pursue it.

for anyone playing the game for the first time, i definitely recommend starting on singleplayer and to change a lot of the world settings (default settings are far from great) like doubling xp gain, harvest and taming speed, and changing the difficulty offset from 0.2 to 1 (will make dinos spawn with much higher levels like on official servers. it both makes dinos more challenging to fight and makes taming them more rewarding)

Most games are better on PC than consoles. Not so for this one. When it comes to ARK the game can be incredibly fun, when it works. I have poured countless hours into the game on PS4, so much so that I have literally memorized 4 maps, and can name nearly every dino if you just give me a general idea of what they look or sound like. 

But when it comes to PC, they somehow made Bethesda look like a saint in terms of bugs, and Ubisoft a saint in terms of optimization. This game will crash on you 24/7, bugs everywhere when it does actually manage to run, to the point where I literally walked not even 4 feet and my game crashed. Now Fallout 3 for example, you can't even play it anymore, but the thing is, at least you can FIX IT. Fallout 3 has had the community solve that problem through custom made patches and workarounds, this game...oh boy this game. 

So in short what im saying, ARK is great, you should get it. Just NOT on PC.

Ark has a fairly strong share of gliches, and, personally, I would prefer a more low-tech approach to the game (sorry, the "Primitive" mod has far too many issues to be playable, so I will discount it for the purposes of this review), but the game is quite... addictive. You will have a blast building your base, taming your dinos, levelling them up, and you will swear as you watch all your hard work wrecked by the lost carnivore that you just don't have the power to stop. Then, you will start again (hopefully not from scratch), and rebuild. I have honestly never played a game that had me cheering at the top of my lungs because I managed to kill something (or, even better I actually knocked that monstrosity out! Hello, new tame!!!!) It's not for everyone - what good game ever is? - but if you like gathering/crafting, and enjoy a challenge, give it a try. You only have everything to lose if you fail...

Lots of fun to be had on the Ark. Highly recommended!
PvE servers are perfect for exploring the HUGE maps and taming dinosaurs along the way. 
While the PvE servers are by no means "safe", PvP servers offer another exhilarating danger to the game as you never know who else you might stumble across. 
Another player, a group, their base? Maybe someone stumbles across your base while you're offline. 
Will they be friendlies? Will you? You can build up your defenses, but will they be enough? 
The answer to all of those questions is most likely NO. 
You WILL spend hours on a base just to see it destroyed. But don't let that turn you away!
Learn to move on and make the best of a bad situation and you will take away some valuable life lessons from this wonderful game.

I'll never forget waking up on the beach, confused, lost, scared.  No tutorial, just alone on a deserted island... naked.  I was just as lost and confused as my character was.  UNTIL ALAS, I FOUND A FRIEND!  We punched trees together until we made ourselves a beautiful little house made of palm leaves.  We discovered the wildlife together and tamed a couple dodos.  After we tamed a couple dodos we decided to bring it up a notch and tame some monkeys and a compy or two.  We were really making a life for ourselves in this strange and new world that we found ourselves in.  Things were great, we had no worries in the world.  No job to go to, no nagging wife to wake up to - just two bros living in paradise... that is, until disaster struck.  On a mid summer evening while we were laying in bed philosophically talking about the island, its origin, and how we got there, we heard loud noises.  My friend peaked his head outside to see what the commotion was.  Upon seeing nothing, he stepped out of our front door just a bit to take a look around.  Within a second, I saw a giant head reach down and snatch him right up.  Just like that, my friend... gone.  Within seconds I heard a loud terrifying roar like it swallowed my friend whole.  Before I knew it, it's massive head was tearing through the roof of our home - well, I guess my home.  I had to think of an exit strategy and quick!  Quickly thinking, I through my monkey Albert at the large and vicious monster.  As the terrifying beast ripped through Albert, I was able to leave through the front door, between the beasts legs and escape.  Running as fast as I could, I never looked back.  I still to this day don't know what the beast was, but I can only assume it was the great T-Rex.  I don't ever plan on going back to find out, and I refuse to get close to anyone else I meet.  The second you get attached, they always go missing or die right in front of your eyes.  #RIPAlbert - your sacrifice saved my life little buddy.  Your sacrifice will never be forgotten, and your son Alberto will carry on your legacy...

This game has one of my favourite theme's and concept's I've seen in a game
but it is absolutely FILLED with some game breaking bugs such as
zones where you can get stuck and have to starve to death, map meshes that aren't aligned with rendered terrain,
terrain that will not let you walk up it, all sorts of stuff.

Creatures can often get stuck in terrain and trees, which while broken has become somewhat of a gameplay feature. My most recent gripe with this game is the genesis expansions which force a sort of pay to win scenario where it is 1000x times easier to level up, harvest and acquire items in the genesis maps, screwing over a lot of regular players.

If you enjoy spending hours grinding while constantly looking behind your back only to lose it all while offline I would recommend

ARK: Survival Evolved is a fantastic game under the right circumstances. I have over 600 hours on this game, so I think I can give you a general idea of whether or now you would like it.

My PC is a MSI Raider GE73, and ARK can run decently well on medium graphics. On my old Alienware, ARK constantly make the PC blue screen on medium. If you're interested in this game, make sure you have decent specs on your PC.

This game is difficult to play alone, or on official servers, due to the toxic community. That being said, if you have a server where you can play with friends, I could not recommend this game enough. Much like Minecraft, there are infinite things to do in this game. There are always structures to build, dinosaurs to breed, and challenges to overcome. I enjoy games with a steady grind to them, but if you don't, the game allows you to tweak the settings so you can avoid that aspect of it.

ARK is a wonderful game with amazing graphics and HUGE maps. Although the game is over 100 Gigabytes, I think if you have a good computer, its worth downloading. I like survival games and this is one of my favorites for many reasons. One of them being the fact that the maps are so huge! It would take a long time to memorize every nook and cranny of it. Another is that youre able to play with friends. I personally like to play singleplayer, but its great that I can easily host my world over their servers at no cost! There are a few settings you need to change for singleplayer to be possible to play though. This isnt the same for everybody but the initial settings are made for multiplayer where multiple people can attack a threat or mine a cluster of resources, so changing them would make it more reasonable to play. Although you may not think it at first, this game has a story you are able to put together by searching for containers of notes left behind by the previous survivors. The story is pretty interesting, but I will not go into spoilers. The bosses are HARD if youre alone. But beating them makes you feel awesome! There are downsides to ARK though. Its very memory hungry for everything, CPU, GPU, and RAM. Also there are occasional bugs and annoyances that can make you scream but the game is so good that even after raging, you'll want to come back right where you left off. It'll be waiting for you.

I really enjoy this game!  It's completely open-world, allowing you to roam, explore, and interact with everything in your environment.  The graphics are great, providing a variety of beautiful settings.  Who wouldn't want to roam the earth with dinosaurs?  Battle them, eat them, tame them, it's up to you. Despite of the sometimes questionable community communication management as well as the whole broken patch implementation process (yes a 16MB patch can take you forever to install it (depending on download region), which is really unfortunate if your whole tribe is in mid of a war), I can recommend this game as it gave me lot of:

- Dinosawrs (yeah)
- Some fantasy animals not even Tolkien could imagine (I am not sure if he thought the nameless should be those annoying fuc**rs as they currently are) 
- Creativity is highly encouraged
- Great friends (also in RL)



Not so good:

- The animals related grind (YOU WILL VISIT THE SWAMP WITH YOUR GIGA REGULARLY)
- The other stuff related grind (you will need a lot for everything)
- The grind for defense/wars (Same as above but in a hussle)

However, as bad as the grind is I personally belief that you will learn to be more efficient, which is a big plus in real life economy. Unfortunately, no one will hire you as you spend 16 hours a day with this game :P.

There are some words of CAUTION for the psychologically weak:

Be prepared that you are going to get sucked in by a  virtual supermassive black hole and it won't release your physical mass into real live again until you hit that "deinstall" button.

I bought this game when it was first released in early access. It gained lots of popularity because it was a shitty early access game that had developers pumping out updates every day.

While the game has gotten more content, basically every bug that has been in the game for 5 years is still there.
-Official servers have a 15 second lag spike every 15 minutes because of save states.
-The AI is atrociously bad. If your pet is on follow and you dont have a clean line, it will get stuck.
-If you lose your pet because the AI is so bad, good luck finding them. 
-Stuck in a wall or a crevice? Have fun starving to death to get out of it. There is no unstuck or suicide button
-When building you have to press a hotkey each time you want to place something. Got 100 walls to place? You'll have to press a button for each one that you place.

I laugh at the fact they priced this at $60 CAD. By no means should you pay more than $20 and even that might cost too much for how many bugs there are.

So, between two accounts I have put well over 15,000 hours into this game from the very beginning, to until very recent. This is a very well thought out game, other then the lore. The games story line is very hidden in a sense of notes and dossiers found around the maps. As for the actual game itself, it is hands down astonishing. The graphics are very clean and crisp easy 10/10, the environment in a sense can feel alive because of so many dinosaurs and creatures about. Now the game has to offer two modes, PVE and PVP. Both modes have their perks to say the least, as for single player goes it can be a lot of fun, but as for multiplayer goes its even more fun. The bosses in this game can be very challenging and difficult, but when you get a sense of how to defeat them, they can become very easy. The game has came along way, it has had its hiccups and its mistakes. I would give honestly give the review a 8/10 overall. Good game, great memories, and met some seriously awesome people in it.

TL;DR: Not worth the time investment - you'll just leave feeling frustrated having spent tens or hundreds of hours on the game.
Game has enough dopamine inducing bits to keep you hooked, but as you level up and need to do more complex tasks you'll end up leaving feeling frustrated with the pathetic game and dinosaur logic. You spend far more than half your time trying to get back to where you were because of it. 
Things like you or your dinosaurs getting stuck walking into a tree or rock (just go around ffs), getting stuck under terrain (yup literally under the ground), or dinos fleeing as soon as you jump out of the saddle because it's still 'following' some dino back at your base. Even mods that help to restore some sort of basic functionality aren't really ideal. You can resort to using cheats to get back to where you were because of these mess ups, but it's still not the same, and you lose half the stuff that you've been collecting.
Oh, and building a base is a NIGHTMARE! Not to mention the inventory & general in-game UI.
You'll spend enough time on the game only to realise that these common problems (check the forums) give everyone gripes but have fallen on deaf ears for many years. The game costs upwards of $US50 a pop, but the developers can't be bothered to fix it. 
Looks great at first and you'll get lots of little dopamine rushes, but later on you'll just leave feeling really annoyed.

Ark is easily my favorite game I've every played. It goes so deep. The gameplay is super fun but also unfair at times. You are weak at first and dinosaurs are strong and merciless. Expect to die (you don't really lose anything when you die as long as you go and get your stuff, though your tamed dinosaurs die permanently). 

My husband and I have made so many amazing moments and memories playing this game together. He captures dinosaurs; I breed them. He hunts; I craft. And we fight all the caves and bosses together using his superior skill and my awesomely bred creatures. We've had soul-crushing upsets and exhilarating victories.

It is a punishing game and would be too difficult for someone with my (low) gameskill to play alone. If you're good at survival games or are looking for a game to play with a family member or friend, I couldn't recommend this game more!

Play style: I play PVE (players can't hurt each other) with my husband on a private server. I personally can't imagine playing on the hyper-competitive official servers. It's fun to watch Youtube videos of Ark players like Kishko but for me personally, the official servers seem depressing because you constantly get raided by other players. Our personal server is hosted on Nitrado. Nitrado's service totally stinks to set up, but works great after it's up and running. We adjusted the settings to make breeding go faster and animals eat less, but other than that we basically play vanilla Ark with the two of us in our own world.

Game Taste Background: I normally play single-player puzzle and dungeon defense games like Divide by Sheep and Dungeon Warfare. For base-building games my favorite one besides Ark has been Rimworld. For multiplayer games, I loved co-playing Minecraft and Diablo 3. 

I hope this review helps someone!

ARK to be completely honest with you is a great promise with a lack of focus or execution. To say the game runs is a miracle in of itself. That being said for the longest time I've played ARK (Nearly 1200 hours) on steam, there's definitely something there that appeals to my brain to spend a good portion of my life on it. 
And what I will say I do love collecting creatures, you can can catch and tame creatures in different ways, some have to be snuck up on and gently offered food, others have to be knocked out with powerful tranquilizer, kept unconscious and fed in a sort of Stockholm syndrome kind of fashion till they love you. 
Which brings me to the crux of the game, ARK was designed with world scale PVP and based around community and tribal cooperation. That being said if you were to play the game on official servers, or on console, It certainly becomes a lot less dino taming; and the existential dread more so waiting for something inevitably bad to happen. Apex predators are powerful thus sometimes if your tribe actually manages to tame a Rex, it's now the 8 hour endeavor of people changing shifts, running back for more narcotics, having enough food to feed it. and the means of protecting the unconscious body as other creatures spawn around you. Not to mention if you are on a PVP server and a rival tribe rolls up and sees what you're doing. 
This doesn't have to be a problem if you play on PC, have mods or edit the multipliers, (Which you don't get to do on console) and play on an unofficial server (Also not available to console players) 
However this still stands as a glaring problem, as it is very committal and leaves no free time for other games, work, or even a shred of social life. At some point ARK will become your life or honestly you won't get anything done in it.
But oh ho! You think mods will solve everything? Another glaring complaint I have with ARK is how they even load mods at its very core. I'm not too knowledgeable on what exactly is going on, but I'll try and explain.
ARK Server has mods in a mod folder, Server starts up, server loads mods. Client-side has to have all the mods downloaded, on their download of ARK, and then to get into the server you have to load all your mods...? It makes no sense to me when if you both have the mods why does it have to load all of them again? If it's validating that everything matches up, fine. Still seems like an extremely outdated way to run things because sometimes getting into the server is literally 30-60 minuets. When I am on I do have a relatively good time, crashes are few and far between (and oh yes even vanilla with no mods you will crash.) On PC you sometimes have to re-validate your files if you're crashing a lot, that might be the one advantage of console is it is bound to be more stable; but then again maybe not. 
So why have I put nearly 1000 hours into this janky ass game? Am I insane? (More than likely) 
What you will get out of ARK in my opinion is some of the best times with friends, the endless hours looking for one rare high level dino, the prettiest one, the ugliest, or one that you have to save, the one that ate what you were taming so you tame it instead. To bond and ride these creatures in a seemingly foreign landscape of extreme biomes and creatures of a handful of wonderful maps created by the community. As you play you will find what creatures you like, don't like, to ride or use. There has been some quality of life updates (Like a rework of the kibble system) that allows you to tame what you want, rather than it being a Noah's ARK (hahahaha get it?) situation. My base will still be like that but I digress. There will be love, loss, heartbreak and occasional mourning for when you learn against a hostile world out to get you. Personally I play PVE and usually in one tribe with all my friends and occasionally randoms that join our server, my whole goal of when I play is to tame scaly nerds and breed them; but there's a whole slew of ways to play.

So would I recommend this game? Uhh, that's a really hard question to answer, to be completely honest. I would definitely look at videos, reviews, and lots of gameplay, don't buy this game blind like I did. I mean I loved it, and would have bought it anyway; but I don't have a very good conscious suggesting people to buy it. I mean I've had a lot of time with it and loved it, from my start of playing it with the lowest settings possible on my old computer, to having it on Ultra graphics on my new PC. My main concern is that someone buys it and starts searching for something they aren't going to find in ARK. It's not a shooter, (despite it being known as shootergame.exe)  it's not a monster brawler, (although it can certainly give that impression) it's a poorly optimized survival based game with tribal, sci-fi, fantasy, and gathering elements. You can Basebuild, fortify, raid, PVP, PVE, colossal fight bosses with immeasurable odds stacked against you. It does have Lore, for whatever that's worth to you. For those who don't fight end game bosses, it seems rather open-ended, needing something you must go out into the world and find, research, look up or find the right dinosaur to harvest it for you. The world can feel large at times, and incredibly small in others. Regardless it waits for you to embrace it and out in the wilds there's a new dino friend just waiting for you to find and tame...or maybe it just wants to eat you..?

The idea for a game is really good, everybody likes dinos. It's a shame that it gets boring after couple of hours - actions become repetitive, building system is not advanced enough to test your creativity - all that is even worse if you played similar survival games.

Some examples of problems you can run into:
 - Dedicated server takes more than 10 minutes to start, that's more than installing and launching the whole operating system
 - Server listing when joining is broken - if you won't put any filters really fast it will load to many servers for the game to handle and crush.
 - As it is common with buggy games, no one cared about making the game run smooth and fast - no matter what hardware you have

ark is an amazing dino game for what it is. first of all it runs better than almost any dino game i have played to this day and on good graphic settings if your pc can handle it the game is truly beautiful. there is hours a upon hours of replayability with the servers being played and some being reset regularly on top of that even in solo worlds there is really just so much to do. although there is much to do in a single played world i recommend playing with a friend its more fun that way and if you dont already have people playing it getting on a server alone may be a bad time getting attacked by clans keeping all your dinos alive and saving your base is a much more difficult task alone and even in a private server having a friend to play with makes it much more fun. there are also a few free dlc that add new dinos new worlds and new items to craft and can make it a entirely new experience. i recommend this to anyone who has a friend and is a lover of dino games and even if you dont think you would play it that often i think its still worth buying on sale. and its also still worth playing if you are solo with no one else to play just be warned you may have a harder time and the game may be a bit slower paced. you can fix this however in any of the worlds you yourself create by increasing the amount of resources and exp you can receive you can also up the dino taming rate so you dont have to sit there for hours risking being attacked wile taming a dino keep in mind this is only for servers you make. same goes for spawning items you can spawn in dions and items in this game in worlds you make you just have to press tab and open the console. then use the correct gfi codes for items and the proper dion id to spawn in what creature you want. these options are good for people who dont care as much to go through the process of farming and building up what you have and just to have fun and see what all the items and dions in the game can do. i have had a lot of fun playing with my brother and i will continue to do so i hope to soon get some of the paid dlcs because the new items and dinos in them look amazing as well on top of the beautiful worlds that come with them. i over all give the game 9 out of 10 because sometimes it can be a bit buggy but its not ever anything that is game breaking or to noticeable. have fun playing the game bois

I have to change my review, once very positive, to not recommended.

This game is just too buggy to play fully.

Every time the server lags (every two seconds), you run the risk of losing your character, and everything you've worked for over the past days, months, or years.

Other bugs suck the joy out of the game as well, and are varied and numerous. Such as the one which currently prevents me from playing on any Official Server--regardless of what I do to fix it.

It's just too grindy to also be so fickle.

I do not recommend buying this game, unless you are just doing it for the heck of it, and want to shell out the forty bucks. However, you can often get the game for $20.00 USA, so it may be worth it just for some casual gameplay.

Many of these negatives are fixed on Unnoficial Servers, as lag is often way down, and friendly admin--who actually play the game--can help if you are wiped.

Outstanding graphics, even when running on a budget gpu. Love the in depth server properties adjustments, feeling like leisure game play just adjust a few sliders to make PVE more laid back play, seeking a challenge adjust the sliders to up the survival challenges, or want a hybrid simply adjust the properties to fit your desired play. Overall rate it a 9/10, some glitchy terrain features and lack of a force save option, without "Cheating" or Admin command, and lack of plot take that one point away.

The games great, I used to play daily as if it were my dream job. I've played all types of servers on Ark. Deathmatch, pve, pvp, both unofficial and official. If you want to play this game just for its survival but dont want a huge grind. Unofficial pve servers are your go to. However, if your looking for a grind, pvp, and fear for your base every time you go to sleep. Play official pvp. If your going to play official pvp find a group, whether you find it on the server or friends. Playing by yourself puts you at a huge disadvantage compared to others. This game will tilt you, make you hate yourself, and regret a lot of things. But the memories I've made having huge tribe wars in official has made me love this game. 

Tl;DR
This game will piss you off but you will love it if you love pvp and grind.

Also dont play on the Chinese servers. (I swear every other chinese server theres a hacker)

I have played ark survival evolved for over 4 years, seeing multiple updates along the way, and now the game is finished (to an extent), it’s time to review it. Truth be told, it is both a fantastic open world survival game, and a depressingly painful one. If you have plenty of free time, you’ll get the most out of it, but if you can’t dedicate a large portion of your life to Ark, you will find yourself to be a very little fish in a very big pond. It can be brutal beyond words, and on the PvP servers you will be punished by other players relentlessly. Dinosaurs of all kinds will tear you limb from limb, and death will become a certainly. Only when it clicks, and you begin to forge a life for yourself on the Ark, does everything become so much clearer. Time is valuable, and it’s up to you to find a way.

I would like to start out by saying, this game is pretty amazing. It's addictive and a hell of a lot of fun for a long time. In its early access, it had a rough start but slowly got better as time went on. With as many hours that I have put into this game it was certainly worth the money. As much as I love the game and want to see it become even better I simply can't give this game a good review. 

PVP:
If you don't already know of the term "alpha tribes", it is a group of people that dedicate their life to this game on a daily basis to ensure that they hold the most power over every other player on the server. This can take many forms, both good and bad. Mostly I have found it to be a negative experience. At a moments notice if this faction of people stops liking you or feels they are threatened by you, or just bored, they can destroy all of your progress without lifting a finger. Every day, week, month you spent building up your base and dino collection, is all for nothing. This cycle continues to repeat itself over and over again until you have finally exhausted every last drop of your will to keep playing. 

A nice feature they added along the development journey is the ability to transfer a player character/inventory/dinos between servers. This has some convenient implementations, such as, you don't need to make a brand new character every time you switch servers. Or someone might come along and wipe out the Alpha Tribe, ushering in a new era of political reign, hooray... oh wait. To bad the new king either doesn't speak english or is more hellbent on wiping lesser tribes than the last guy. With that said, it is highly likely that at some point someone will transfer over into your server and wipe everyone out within a day. 

PVP servers boil down too, get s*** on or be the top dog. Either way you will be consuming a lot of time. 

PVE:
I finally got around to trying PVE, and thought that I have finally found a part of this game that I can play without ruining my experience. Nope... PVE servers are the equivalent of a communist utopia. Since there is no reliable way to clear our other players or dinos, servers quickly become inflated and most if not all the land in the map is claimed (at least reasonable land). To top this off, a server has a "dino cap". Which essentially means that the total sum of all owned dinos can only exceed a certain threshold before the server says "no more". New players will have no way of progressing until other players dispose of tames. All the while older players can no longer breed dinos and in short the server stagnates or dies off. Plenty of people have started forums and chats about this issue but to no relief. 

PVE in short is unplayable. 

Single Player/COOP:
Unfortunately, a lot of the charm of this game is in its community. Minus all the crap, there is fun to be had with other players whether trading, working alongside, or just general company. So playing solo or with close friends on your own server might be the way to go, but it seems more or less pointless without others IMO.


In my conclusion. Save yourself the time, money and frustration. Pick up another game instead..

This game is a great game. I love being able to build anything from a metal box in PvP to a palatial mansion on PvE. You can even build a town with your tribe mates! I will say Official servers aren't fun at all to play on. PvP players are generally jerks on Official and it makes it completely not fun. Official PvE servers are very crowded with huge bases and they will "thatch block" the areas around by placing thatch foundations down making it hard to find a decent place to build. They also lag really really bad. 

UnOfficial servers are totally the way to go!! They generally have nice rules, better rates and most of the time, quality of life mods that make the game so much better to play. Once I found unofficial I've never looked back. 

I love being able to build and have the freedom to build whatever your mind can imagine. Taming is fun and you can really get into breeding and make the best dinos possible. 

I love the different events and holidays that give us cool colored dinos. Easter is the absolute best!!

The game is a bit buggy for sure, but totally worth the money!!

ARK is a decent game for anyone that likes survival, dinosaurs, crafting etc., and it is addicting game for sure. With friends it's a fun game to spend hours upon hours on. 
That said - what me and my friends (who also have this game) agree on, is that this game has some bugs and problems that need to be fixed ASAP - but instead of getting those fixed, the devs keep on making new content that can be sold to the players.

Don't get me wrong; this game is playable! Just not 100% enjoyable due to the issues it has. It is a fun game and despite the problems, I would still have to recommend it because I enjoy playing it. Even if this means that the lazy and greedy devs won't fix the problems it has, but instead keep on producing content (eg. maps) that can be turned into profit.

I thoroughly enjoy this game, although it does need a few mods to get the most out of it. Beautiful scenery to the point its impossible to settle on a base spot.  My major complaint is the startup. It is extremely slow to load in, and often requires blind faith that it hasn't frozen in the process, as that is what it appears to do at first. After a few minutes, it will switch the loading screen and its safe sailing from there. I know mods have some to do with this, but a more positive indicator that the game is still working while loading would be a definite plus. The settings sliders can be a little confusing, even with the descriptors but not impossible.
You need a good gpu, but apart from that it is a great game. In total 9/10 for needing a good gpu
grind is life

This game has so much to offer. No matter your play style you are able to find enjoyment out of this game whether you want to play pve or pvp, alone, with friends or in a huge tribe. All the features of this game are so in depth that it will take you so long to get through them all, hence the 1000 hours... and I've barely scratched the surface. All the DLC's offer brand new content that changes the way people play this game so would highly recommend investing into them.

While there are some performance issues and some bugs still in the game, the developers have been good with pushing out updates to help address these issues. In saying that, anyone with a low end computer should NOT get this game. The frustration is not worth it trust me this is coming from experience.

I think if the developers were to focus on the optimisation and bug fixes the game would be a lot more accessible to a lot of people which would increase the longevity of this game and more importantly increase the enjoyment that people would have with this game (as well as increase profits for developers of course).

All in all fantastic game that still has heaps of room for development and optimisation but definitely worth the buy if your computer can handle it.

I hopefully have come to a final conclusion on this game. It sucks. 

ARK: Survival Evolved is a great game, but there are certain things that I just cant look past.

Everytime I re-download ARK, it usually lasts about 60 hours before I quit and delete the game. I dont know what it is about this game but it always manages to infuriate me and any of m friends that own this game. every. single. fucking. time.

Basically what it boils down to is PVP is annoying because you reach a certain point and you get demolished by a rival tribe and all you can do is rebuild. until you get wiped again by the same tribe.

PVE is boring because once you reach a certain point, you WANT PVP. but if you had played PVP, you wouldnt reach the point where you want it.

This game is amazing depending on the server you join, but it can also be the absolute worst game you have ever bought. 

ARK was the first game I purchased on this account, I biught the game before the 60 dollar price hike, way back when the games base price was 25 dollars. I bought it during the winter sale for 15 dollars and it was a great game for that price at the time of purchase but it eventually became a toxic hellhole.

hopefully I dont re-write this again.


Edit: WOW!! I am back again with more proof that ARK: SE is utter garbage! This time I am not rewriting the whole thing for the 3rd time, Instead I am here to talk about the design falws of PVE!! Basically you think that PVE is not PVP at all, and that greifing would not be a problem? Wrong! If you have a tribe member go rogue, they can blow the whole base skyhigh. They can unclaim dinos (Depending on Tribe settings) They can destroy everything you have build over the last 50 hours of gameplay and take what is left into a new tribe, removing your access! This game is terrible, and I dont know why I keep coming back.

I have played about 480 hours of Ark, and there is quite a few things people should know. I got it on sale for about £9 so i could join my friends on their own private server. It is not worth anything above £20! The game has so many bugs, so many glitches, but Wildcard refuses to fix any of them. They just keep adding new maps. Regardless, the game is a lot of fun. Playing on a private server was extremely helpful to me, so i could learn everything about the game from my friends, but after a while we started playing on other public servers like MTS, to actually enjoy the game fully. 

Things to know before you get this game:
1. It is very buggy. Be prepared to log in one day and the mods have corrupted or something like that.
2. It takes quite a lot of time to actually understand the game properly. I only started to actually enjoy the game when I realised it didn't matter that my pet dodo I had for three days died to a random raptor.
3. Try to watch videos about stuff in the game, like what animals do what, what the meta is for pvp, settings etc.

Apart from that I don't really know what to say. It is a great game, but don't spend £45 on it. wait for a sale.
