This is a tough one in many ways. It's easily in my top 5 favorite games, but at the same time I absolutely would not recommend it at base price. $50 is way too much to ask considering how the developers have treated this game so far.

That's not to say that the gameplay is not worth $50, cause it absolutely is, but considering the lack of support in certain areas I wouldn't pay that price.

Luckily it very frequently goes on sale for sub-$20, and very commonly around the $10 range. Absolute steal for that price, even with everything else considered.

Grab a couple copies, one for you and a friend or two and so long as you stay away from official PvP and default rates you will have the time of your life.

P.S: I have roughly 450 hours on my other account. This is next to nothing compared to some people, but figured I'd mention it cause it's a whole lot better than the 45 or so hours I have on here.

ARK is a pretty decent game if you're playing with friends. It isn't the best because it has a lot of bugs, and every new update adds bugs. Also, there are pretty frequent updates that are usually around 2 GB, and the file size constantly gets bigger (the game was a little bit less than 50 GB when I first got it, but now it's 121 GB). The game requires a very good PC to run. The price was fine when it was $20, but when they took it out of beta, it went up to $60. The only reason they took it out of beta was to justify making DLC, but there are way to many bugs for this to be a full game. On top of that, the multiplayer sucks. Most public servers will have an alpha tribe, so they can do whatever they want. You're able to server transfer, which means you can take your stuff to another server, so a lot of people randomly transfer to servers and demolish people's hard work for no reason. If you stop playing for as little as ten minutes, someone can easily destroy your base. Overall, this game is not the best unless you have friends to play with, a good computer, and you get it on sale.

This is one of those games that is on my top ten list for most hours played.

Being new to the game, there is so much to explore. Different areas with different resources which allow you to build different things. Unlike other survival games, this one can be difficult to get stared and you actually feel a sense of accomplishment as you obtain different goals. Also unlike other survival games, this one is very much centered on taming and training your dinosaur army.

Dinosaurs all have different abilities and things they are good at. For instance, you train a beaver to get wood, you train an anky to get metal, you train a doedicorous to get stone, you train a rex for combat, and an arge to fly around.

You go from the stone age tech through a metal based tier, and finally to a futuristic tech teir, which requires you to kill bosses and obtain the engrams.

There are many many ways to play this game. You can play single player one map at a time, you could start your own server cluster and transfer from map to map pulling the easiest to obtain dinos and resources from each to accelerate your climb to power, you could play with a friend or two cooperativly, or you could go play PvE or PvP or both on one of the thousands of dedicated servers. 

You can customize the game to the extreme. You can crank up gathering rates, tame rates, birth rates, etc. if things are too grindy for you. Or you can flex and claim you got zero to tek on an official server with no boosted settings. You can customize your level, the dino levels, how much you eat, etc.

The game really is a unique experience and is probably responsible for many of the survival craft games that came after it.

I enjoyed my time with this game, but I can't ignore all of its flaws. A lot of my fun came from joining a semi-established tribe early on and learning a lot about the game from that point on. 

The overall gameplay loop is pretty fun. Get materials. Tame creatures. Use eggs to make kibble. Train more creatures. Use those creatures to help you get more materials to both tame and upgrade your base more efficiently. It's pretty fun until the end game when all you effectively do is go on metal runs with harvester dinosaurs and min/max your tames.

This game, atleast back when I played it, is terribly optimized and full of bugs. From what I've read, this has not been fixed since the game came out of early access. You'll need a fairly beefy computer to run this game at consistent FPS on higher settings. Some of the bugs and glitches are good fun, especially when they happen in a call with friends. Others have the potential to get hours of work destroyed. 

You see the one thing this game doesn't advertise is politics. If you hope to get anywhere in this game, you gotta know how to deal with other tribes, especially the Alpha Tribe. If you do this poorly, you'll probably end up getting locked in a cage by the alpha tribe for as long as they want (essentially keeping you from playing the game). Getting everything you worked so hard on destroyed overnight by server hoppers or poor relations is also just a terrible feeling, especially when the Alpha Tribe continues to stop any effort of rebuilding forcing you to move to a different server to be able to play again.

Don't even get me started on the DLC. I mean they pushed this stuff out in early access while the main game wasn't even close to being complete. Also they introduced these super strong creatures that can be taken to different servers and used to obliterate everyone. They sort of just left a bad taste in my mouth.

This is a "single player" review. This game was not intended for single player apparently because I had to google how to play a single player game. Not even a real single player game. Too many choices for starting a new game. I just want to be able to hit a "New Game" button and choose my difficulty, not have to choose amongst 49 (I counted) different game variables before I start. For a game that's a builder it's complete sh it! If I'm forced to spend a great deal of time building structures to meet game requirements, then they had better implement excellent building tools. The building in this game is abysmal. Google the sh it. The first buildings at the beginning of the game were such a fuc king chore and never turned out properly. The stairs didn't match the building, they would fit properly and when I tried to use them I couldn't get up the stairs without crawling. The roof wouldn't go on. No, that's not entirely true; the roof was able to go on the side of the building, not the top. I thought roofs went on top of buildings. It was just one giant clusterfu ck. To top it off it had shi tty controls and clunky movement. The graphics are very poor on medium setting. I have a decent rig that can run most stuff on high settings and this game suffers immensely from stutters and lag. I had no fun at all playing this turd.

So after playing a couple dozen hours in this game I have uninstalled it.  There are serious fundamental problems with this game.  
- Balance: the imbalance issues in this game are so drastic that you need to adjust the integrated environment sliders just to be able to see serious long-term development of your character.  You can play hours harvesting resources, refining metals, leveling up to unlock new patterns, going on long expeditions to get rare materials, build yourself high-end equipment and weapons and still die in under 10 seconds because some raptor with a bug up it's ___ decides you look like a snack.  That's not fun, that's just pure and utter frustration

- Graphic/Engine: the graphics in the game, even in ultra-high settings, are pretty dated.  That in and of itself is not a significant issue, there are plenty of great games with lower end graphic detail, but what is most terrible about this game, and quite impactful to gameplay are the creature models and clipping.  Imagine a giant murder-chicken ripping you apart and you shooting for your life in the 10-20 seconds you have before you die, only to realize that the thing's hit-box doesn't render correctly and you're "hitting" it but not "hitting" it.  

- Game Progression: Quite honestly the progression system in this game is one of the worst i've seen in any type of game recently.  You level up to unlock new "engrams" which are basically crafting patterns. You can spend points you get each level to also increase stats such as max hp, max stamina, etc.  However most of the stats you put points into affect multiple things of which no tool-tips key you into.  I hope you like wiki-searching because without it you have no hope of advancing in this game as there's no in-game knowledge system or hints for where to find super rare resources or how to tame anything properly. 

Uniqueness: the game's theme for taming dinosaurs is great and very unique, but when it actually comes to taming them the mechanics behind them are HORRIBLE. Like...imagine creeping up on a Rex, shooting a tranq-dart and then running away until you're out of stamina.  Now imagine having to do that 50-80 times.  You're talking literally hours of solid game-play to subdue a single pet. Oh and if he catches you, you're dead, not a chance at death, you're just dead. And not just that, but now the armor/weapons/gear you made, which took DAYS of playtime to get are now sitting in his pathing area and he will keep killing you even if you manage to make it back to your body (of which there's no beacon or marker on a map where there's not even a 'you are here' symbol).  

Ultimately I gave this game a lot of slack because it fits a lot of niches that i really like.  Exploration, resource gathering, base building, hunting/survival, but in the end it is just so frustrating i can't tolerate it.  After dying about 2 dozen times trying to get the equipment I spent days acquiring, all with game settings tweaked just to make it more enjoyable and less of a grind I just had enough of it and uninstalled it. It's not fun. Fun is challenge, not being slaughtered without a chance.

This game remains one of my all time favorites, and I would 100% recommend it for anyone who loves survival/tame games. 
It does take a pretty good computer to run it though, and it is not as fun without friends to tribe up with.

I've spent 200 hours in this game. I've really tried to enjoy it, but I just can't. From the way you tame creatures to the incredible grind even with multipliers. My final stopping point was the leveling system. I understand leveling up creatures to make them stronger, and leveling yourself up to get higher survivability, but why on Earth do you need to level up to craft certain things? Especially when leveling a survivor takes so long? Not to mention the most common taming method of knocking out a creature then feeding it meat for 30 minutes. Quality content! You know what I find even better though? Raising an egg in real time! The animal really matures with me. You know the saying they grow up so fast? This doesn't apply in Ark. Not to mention the constant graphical glitches, creatures getting stuck in each other, character files getting deleted, poor optimization, and just incompetent developers. Not to mention the K no collision which is just basically vanilla wallhacks. Don't even get me started with spawning right next to predators like terror birds, raptors, etc. This game has so many issues that I'm debating which ones to mention just to keep this a little bit short. I do not recommend you buy it. At the very least buy it on sale. It is a horrible game.
this game is best

Starting off, this is a game that has issues. No game is perfect, and I think that perfection is an unrealistic standard to hold anything to. Hit registration could use some work, many maps have spots where the visible model doesn't match up with where your character collides with the terrain, creature pathfinding is atrocious, and many glitches/exploits have existed in the game for a long time that do require addressing. But, I still enjoy the game. 

For the first 1200 hours that I logged in the game I didn't beat a single map, I didn't fight a single boss, I didn't even complete a cave. I just explored, tamed creatures, and built amazing structures. The basic mechanics of the game were enough for me to log 1200 hours and enjoy almost all of them. Over the years the addition of more official maps/creatures, as well as some amazing maps/creatures from the modding community have kept the game alive for me. even without exploring any of the endgame/story content.

After logging my 1201st hour I decided to attempt to complete the first map that was added to the game, the island. I recruited a few friends to play with and I rented a multiplayer server from a third party hosting company. Beating the island is a grueling task. 10 caves, 3 guardians, and the final ascension boss/cave combo at the top of the volcano are extremely difficult. I spent another couple months, and 500 hours completing this task. This single map that comes with the base game had enough content to keep me and a friend engaged for months. It had its ups and downs, we got bored at some stages, and sometimes you can feel like there isn't anything that you can do to progress, but if you look for it, then it is there. If you are looking for a long term, grindy, but rewarding survival experience then the base game could be for you. (Screenshots from this run are on my profile)

Moving on to the DLC's. (I have not beaten each of these completely, these are my scattered thoughts from the time that I have spent on them)

Scorched earth came out very early on in ark's development, and I think that it could use some love from the devs. It didn't receive an ascension cut scene similar to all of the other paid DLC, and it seems to lack some of the unique content that is present in them as well. Overall I enjoyed the experience still. The content that they did add is a fresh and interesting change of pace from the island, and the addition of the egg stealing mechanic can not be overlooked. The caves on this map are fantastic, I love the adventurous feel that they all have.  The new weapons and structures all look great as well. Sometimes the weather effects feel like a bit much, it would have been nice for end game engrams to be available that help you combat them, rather than them just stopping gameplay for a few mins. Overall I think that Scorched is worth it, as long as you enjoyed the base game already, though it would have been nice for an ending to have been added to the progression.

Aberration. Overall this may be my favorite DLC. The subterranean vibe is impeccable, and once again coming from the flyer heavy previous maps I think that their removal was a perfect way to distinguish gameplay on this map from others. The creatures DLC exclusive creatures on this map are so much fun. The ravager is a fantastic earlygame mount. With its ability to climb ziplines and vines it is almost essential for new players to travel the map with. The rockdrake is difficult to obtain, but completely worth it. The gliding and climbing mechanics are fairly intuitive and fun to use. The reaper has a unique "taming" method that separates it from all other creatures in the game. I never tamed the big crab, but it looks sick, and is a fantastic way of farming up polymer. On top of this the new items added by the DLC make map traversal easier, and more enjoyable on foot for any map. They are almost essential for anyone playing on a no tames server. This section is getting rather long, so lets just say that I recommend this DLC.

Extinction was a mixed bag for me. I like the new creatures, mechanics, map, and items, but the progression feels a bit skewed. I understand that this is intended to be the ultimate challenge for large tribes to complete. It is difficult, and the rewards for tasks are immense. But as a mostly solo player some of the tasks feel a bit too impossible. It is doable, if you put in the time. People have soloed this DLC. Maybe it just isn't for me.

As I am writing this review I haven't spent a ton of time in the Genesis Part One DLC, but what I have seen I have greatly appreciated. The addition of missions as a means of progressions breaks up some of the monotony of the core gameplay loops. As well as the taming methods for all of the new creatures. It feels like the devs really went out of their way to spice the game up, and provide the player with much more to do. The Biomes are beautiful. and the new tools, tekgrams, and structures are a ton of fun to mess around with. I am looking forward to attempting this DLC legit, and completing it as well.


Overall my advice would be don't buy the entire package right away. Start with the base game and free DLC maps. Play around with it. have fun. see what works best for you and see which aspects of the game you enjoy most. If you dont really care about the story of the game, but you enjoy exploring, taming new creatures, and building bases, then get scorched. If story, and lore, and progression are the most important aspects of the game to you then purchase the DLC's that cater to that. Aberration, Extinction, and Genesis (One at a time, don't necessarily purchase them all at once. That is a lot of content and you might burn out before then). If the core gameplay loop gets too repetitive, and you want to try playing some brand new concepts in the ARK framework then go straight for Genesis. The sheer amount of content that is available in this game is fairly staggering. There is something in there for almost every type of player.

I short, I like the game, I am happy with the money I have spent on it, and I am happy with the time that I have invested in it. Maybe I will come back with more as I continue to play through the DLC's with the goal of total completion of the game.

I really like this game. But people are NOT kidding about how horrible this game's state is in.

Pros:
- 3D Minecraft with dinosaurs
- Gorgeous landscapes 
- Endless discoveries to be made
- Progression is very satisfying
- Single Player is fantastic for new players

Cons: (How tempted i am to say everything else...)
- Rancid player community
- Enough bugs to make Bethesda jealous
- Really shoddy performance sometimes
- Constant and incessant updating with no real improvements

Oh and this game is what, 5 years old? It's STILL on early access and has uh...hold on. Abberation...Scorched earth...Genesis...Genesis part 2...Extinction...That's 60 USD for all three DLC...and another 70USD for Genesis DLCs?

This game was infamous for releasing an expansion before finishing the motherehffing game and now they have FIVE WHOLE DLC EXPANSIONS and this game is STILL a buggy mess. Seriously. Skyrim on crack this one is.

Like...I must have gone thru hell and back to get me a super sweet monstrous Reaper Tame...and he was so busted I could solo one of the island bosses with him when i brought him over. I was having a gay ol time. Until the game decided to thanos snap him to oblivion while i was offline. This is single player btw so it's not like anyone was pulling a fast one on me. I log on and he's simply gone. use a mod to track my dinos, everything but him is accounted for. he doesn't even exist. I've seen so many people complain about this frankly game breaking issue and people who  play on official servers are just straight up fhhucked. 
I put in all that time and effort and my reward for paying all that money and spending 300hrs on ark and it's DLC is a good ol simpsons style F-You and "HA~HA~"?

Triggered? Yeah. I am. Are you saying you wouldn't be? Well I guess that's fair. Most ppl nowadays have been trained to have no attachment to their money or what they blow it on so they'd probably be content with buying a literal bag of burning turds if a game dev told them it was gonna get good eventually.

I have no idea what the developers were thinking, but after 5 years, this game has no bloody excuse for being in such a sloppy state.

Finish your game, get your ass outta early access, THEN shyyt out DLC like hotcakes. That's the order it should be done...and even if the developer has a skele crew...ALL THE MORE REASON TO SIDELINE THE DLC D:< 

All that aside...I played 300hrs for a reason. The game is good...when it's not busy collapsing in on itself...and I was ready to edit my review in a positive light with how much fun abberation was after recently trying it, but...no...this is the straw that broke my back.

Buy it on sale if you must...otherwise buy it ONLY if you have a friend or two who will actively play with you and you can buy a private server. Cause otherwise...your experience is gonna be akin to rolling dice.

Started playing this dame about 6 weeks ago. I have played mostly on my PVE unofficial server I rent. My buddy and I have practically played this game everyday for at least 3-5 hours. We love it. Once we tweaked the settings slightly due to not being in a huge tribe it makes it really fun and not making resource gathering a chore. Its a super fun survival (best one I have played yet). We ended up getting the complete edition this weekend due to the sale. You can do whatever you would like. Build, Farm, Explore, Fight, Breed and Tame dinos! There are so many different types of dinos across each map and we have only played the Island and Crystal Isles. Land dinos, flyers and water.  You can go exploring in caves, it has multiple biomes in each map, hands down think this game is great. I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking looking for a solid survival type game. If you play Ark the way the developers made the vanilla experience, you will think it's one of the worst games to ever exist. And you would be right too.

The vanilla experience is beyond "no life", it's literally trading your real self for your Ark self. The amount of "time based" tasks is insane. 6 hours to tame something? Who the fuck is over the age of 25 and has 6 hours to do that on a REGULAR BASIS? If I played vanilla I would have tamed appx 2-3 big dinos PER MONTH... which is insane. You can beat The Outer Worlds in less time than it takes to tame a big dino that's max level.

Just everything about the vanilla game is blocked behind ridiculously unnecessary time blocks. It just takes so long to do absolutely anything. In order to have a functioning real life, and play this game, you need to find a dedicated server or just start your own for you to play co-op on with tame rates x10 ,harvest rates x5, and then a mod to adjust weight/stacks.

If you are planning to buy this game for PvP don't bother at all:

The audio is miserably bad, like I'm talking someone can C4 your base from 10 feet away and you wont hear a thing. Most servers have one tribe who rules the entire server and makes it impossible for anyone else to play on it. You probably think, "oh I'll just join another server" but yeah no they are there too, the game allows you to transfer things between servers so alpha tribes can come on to a new server, and begin steamrolling just like they would on their main server. You can have months worth of content all wiped in a few seconds by an unstoppable zerg. Think you have enough friends to fight them off? Don't bother, the servers have hard set limits to 70 players, which means some of these zergs will consume 90% of the population pool, even if you wanted your friends to come help you, they can't. It's not like Rust with 300-400 player servers. 

People say "the community is toxic" but they aren't. They are just playing the game the way Wildcard provided, and Wildcard provided one of the absolute worst PvP experiences to ever exist. I don't blame the large clans because Wildcard has given these large clans the tools and ability to make servers unplayable. Until this game can implement 3D audio, and a  way to have PvP without players losing months/years of work, (ORP is not the solution when alpha tribes will just build a wall around the area your ORP protects) the PvP will continue to be the worst in survival games.

"bro, ur review is positive, all you've done is talk smack"

Because regardless of Wildcard being incompetent to PvP experiences, they have built a game that is incredibly vast and can provide thousands of hours of fun in co-op. They have provided you with the ability to run your own custom game with the click of a button, with sliders that can affect every game setting down to how often you poop. You can literally build YOUR OWN PERSONAL Ark experience. And I respect the hell out of WC for implementing such a feature. I complain about vanilla but realistically I've only spent maybe ~100 hours on official servers. The rest of my time has been enjoyed either on single player or in private servers. There is so much to do in Ark and there is so much to discover. I couldn't even begin to tell the stories I've had with this game. And considering how ambitious this game is, I also give them props on it actually running..

Overall: Buy it to play with your friends, buy it to play single player. Adjust game settings so that the time walls are more reasonable, and get a stacks mod to avoid spending 12 hours farming. The competitive multiplayer is beyond bad it's a joke and isn't worth anyone's game time. Wildcard dev team has obviously never played a real PvP game in their lives.

Many promises were made.  Many were never delivered yet...this has matured into the archetype of the genre. 

Personally, due to the decay system, I would not play it on anything but a private server. This became the curse of survival games and why they died a death after this. 

But on a private server, it really is a beautiful game. Ii there was one thing that could have saved it in general,  it would be a better claim and decay system.  Just like every game of this type.  

You survive, gather your food and water, build a massive variety of structures (Ark really really excels at this ( WITH MODS, IT IS HALF THE GAME ALONE), especially with mods which make the vanilla suck a lot less), create your clothes/armour, adapt and hunt in a prehistoric island type environment.  You can tame and use the local wildlife which also levels.   You can craft a wide range of objects and buildings etc from scratch.  The crafting system is very good. As is the construction though to really fly, you can mod it to avoid annoying snap to limitations and add lots of variety to an already feature rich construction environment. 

I think it would be fair to say that this game created a genre. It is up to developers where it goes from here. Conan and DnL were not a patch on it because they were part of Steam Early Access. Which is the graveyard of good ideas.

The thing which is hard to convey is the depth within this game. It has depth in all of the key areas. You feel like this is the game you wanted when you read the intro rather than you got cheated by someone marketing  features just like ticks on a list then not bothering to deliver anything meaningful.   Building alone accounts for the vast majority of my time in the game. So much variety and detail.  Particularly on a modded self run server. 

On official servers, it is nauseatingly grinding and the thing you grind so hard for (especially when it comes to taming), just isn't worth it.  There is literally no reason to buy it to play on official servers. It is terrible.

So, a classic game and an archetype of its genre. If you like building, survival and base building. It is the best in its class.  But play it on a non official server as they destroy it.

But the mods are really making this great.  The vanilla experience is dull and banal, but the moddability seems to really bring it to life.  Many great mods to liven things up and add some depth and keep you playing.  Being that the environment is very beautiful, this works very well indeed. A great pity that the moddable nature of the product did not go much further.

Having said that, a lot of people I like and I would most like to play with absolutely hate this game. The grindingly idiotic gameplay puts most people off in official mode.  You would have to be out of your mind to play on a normal server.  They basically did not help themselves when it came to making the game fun and even a little bit reasonable. 

The sheer computer power required to run it in any mode that looks nice can be a thing for some.

BUT - Make your own server and pay very very careful to your configuration and it can be both challenging and enjoyable without sucking like hell.  The addition of many many mods to add some much needed depth really can bring it to life. It can have an economy, trading system, and a much more alive eco system that the blandness of the vanilla experience.

ARK, truly has been one of my most favorite games released since early 2016. I followed ARK religiously until the release on consoles as my laptop wasn't able to run this stupidly beefy game.
Basically; if you're into survival games in which you need to forcefully enslave prehistoric creatures to aid you in surviving, congrats!
Ark has: Gameplay - You play as a dropped specimen with prehistoric creatures. Build, Tame, Survive. You really only can play so much until you burn yourself out since its repetitive. HOWEVER the community's side of modding is a chefs kiss. Bringing new challenges (or changes) to vanilla ark. 
STORY - Not many players pay attention to the story behind ark and the past survivors who studied the entire life of the Island since its not shoved in your face like any other game, to find the lore and the story you must find explorer notes. They're scattered all across every single map. Goodluck. Took me till this month.
OF Servers - Both ranging PVP and PVE. 
DLC - SE to Genesis, man youre expensive. worth it.
B.U.G.S - Sometimes this game isn't bad, what makes a bad gameplay is the bugs. I cannot express myself anymore. I am sick of falling through the world because some overgrown lizard chomped my body into oblivion. 
HOWEVER, you NEED a beefy PC! For some ungodly reason ARK eats more than my ex, taking a whooping 150GBS and chomps on my RAM. save some space for the little guys :(

I personally love ark. Despite the flaws, I love this survival and the amount of stupidity that goes into it :) a dino game that can accomplish both: a story and gameplay is rare.

After 5 years this game still has a litany of issues.  I didn't buy it when it first showed up on steam because I knew it would have a host of bugs and I'm tired of being an unpaid beta tester for these devs.
- tamed dinos disappear, 5 year issue still not resolved.
- abysmal building system, but they do what all devs do and wait for someone to mod it properly because they are too lazy to do it right the first time. 5 year issue.
-dinos horrible pathing.  some how an Alpha Rex can appear out of thin air but but a tamed raptor can't path around a rock on a beach.  If you have any dinos following you, you have to turn around every few seconds to make sure they are still there. 5 year issue.
- there's no way to effectively exclude dinos if that's what you want, any .ini file settings that are out there don't work.
- had to change the auto-save timer from 15 minutes to 5 minutes due to instability of tamed dinos.
- having to constantly leave the game to research things because the game does a piss poor job informing you of anything.  If you do figure something out like a recipe, you still have to pause out of the game to remember how it is done.  Once a recipe is discovered and figured out it should always be available  so I don't have to reference outside of the game.

Never have I spent more time outside of a game, researching how to do things in the game, than this. 10-20% of my playtime is spent in wikis or forums trying to understand how things work.  The devs dont fix issues but manage to keep putting out content.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This game will sadly never be good.
It is such an amazing concept, but Wildcard's questionable decision-making has doomed this game.

The downfall of this game originally stems back to the implementation of cross-transfers between servers back in the scorched earth days, which caused an influx of alpha tribes obliterating server after server. People tried blocking the obelisks and supply drops, and eventually it calmed down slightly. 

Since then the game has never been the same, with map-exclusive dinos (particularly extinction dinos) being transferred everywhere and wiping base after base, with no way for small tribes to even exist, even on small-tribes servers.

There is simply no way to survive anymore on official, as your base will be found and destroyed before you can make any substantial progress.

Even the best defences, (heavy turrets, doubled walls, vaulted walls, etc.) won't last a minute due to massively overpowered dinos like the gasbag, MEK, managarmr etc.

Meshing is still a problem, and allying mega tribes on small tribe servers (where allying is NOT ALLOWED) still exists to this day.

The servers are a complete joke. The never-ending lag is just ridiculous, and servers will go down for hours at a time, with no explanation (or even recognition) from Wildcard, causing people to lose dinos, items, characters and hard work.

Single-player is boring as multiplayer is how this game is designed to be played, and unofficial servers run the risk of being randomly shut down if the owner decides to stop paying hosting fees. Also unofficial servers also commonly have admins that give themselves an unfair advantage over everyone else, making progress impossible once again.

The game still has bugs from when I started playing ARK on Xbox One in 2016, and due to the amount of content that has been added / changed, the game hasn't become any more bug free than what it was back then.

The performance of the game has only improved very slightly since the beginning, and it still runs awfully, even on high end GPU's and CPU's.

No matter how much content they add, and even if they remove map-exclusive dino transfers between maps, fix bugs and improve performance, I don't think this game will ever recover from WIldcard's past and present decision-making, leading this game into obscurity, where the only ones left playing are allied mega tribes with no-one left to raid.

I've reviewed this game before but I've played about 300 more hours since then. So, here's an honest to god review. 
1) This is, hands down, the MOST frustrating game I have EVER played. I have played a LOT of games so that says a lot. 
2) **HOWEVER** (with the right people!) hosting your own server (SUPER EASY!) for JUST your friends (SERIOUSLY, REALLY EASY) is VERY fun. 
3) Some of these maps are absolutely stunning. The next closest thing I've seen to gorgeous scenery is maybe Skyrim V. (Skyrim V tops ARK though). 
4) You have to INDIVIDUALLY buy ALL the DLCS unless you buy a SEASON PASS! This is VERY VERY annoying! I personally have not played Genesis so I can't speak to how interesting it is, but I have all the other ones which ARE fun. SEASON PASSES are also very helpful when they're on sale! 
5) Overall the game runs alright. I run ARK on a low graphic low ram $750 crapola computer and it does OK. Don't get me wrong, I'm not going to be competing in any gaming comps with it, but it does alright.
6) What other users with negative reviews have said is true - some of the bugs from eons ago have not been fixed. The tek car is kind wack... mine made it's way into the ocean. It's also virtually indestructible. They nerfed birds and mounts - but the single player game is very customizable to what you want your player experience to be like. 
7) This game updates ALL THE TIME and they take FOREVER if you have slow internet! Mine is updating as I write. Keep that in mind before you buy. 
8) Last thing - the game is very addicting. No, I'm serious. VERY. If you like dinosaurs, and I mean like even slightly, you're going to ignore the faults of the game, pay the $30 or $60 and play this stupid game and love it and its glitchy wibbly wobbly dino stuff. 

So that's my two cents. 8/10 for the game overall. 9/10 for the story line. 7/10 for the bug fixes. Good luck.

You are able to view through the mesh, walk in the mesh, and even build in the mesh. This alone makes this game a total failure. There are extreme rubber banding, de-sync, and hitbox bugs. Instead of fixing some core issues of the game, the developers are adding more and more incomplete and buggy DLC's. I won't speak about the official servers because you cant play on them while having a life, there are no official alternatives which allow working people to participate on the original game. Instead you have to play on unofficials with mods, regular wipes, and even more bugs. I would really like to recommend this game. But i swear STAY AWAY from it... To play it you don't have to learn the games features, you have to learn how to use AND abuse bugs and exploits in order to compete with others.

While the game is buggy, and will melt your computer if you don't have something extremely powerful, it is a very fun survival game, albeit very frustrating and slow sometimes. I admit, I use mods, cheats, and increased rates to make it better, default rates are painfully slow, so if you don't want to waste 2 days taming a t-rex, increase your rates. The building is also a bit wonky, you may be trying to make your roof tilt up, but instead, it'll either tilt down for no reason and blip around unless you add sloped walls to force it to point up, or you accidentally demolish a wall with the wall you were trying to place because you nudged your mouse and pointed down instead of on top. Try not to build too fast to avoid making mistakes like this, but at least there's a 30 second window to pick up misplaced structures. The game also revolves around the unique Tek tier of buildings and weapons which you earn from the 3 bosses in the late game, more DLCs add more "Tekgrams" later on. As for the DLCs and Maps:

The Island
The most "polished" map, per se, it has the largest amount of available creatures, and is the closest to a true dinosaur survival game with limited fantasy aspects. It has a variety of biomes to build in and harvest from, but as a trend for most of ARK's maps, it lacks in truly flat ground to build on, and is very hilly in some areas. Nevertheless, the variety of creatures to tame, places to build in, and the most amount of water overall than any other map makes it one of the easier ones to play in.

Scorched Earth
My favorite map and favorite mechanics, but compared to the other DLCs, it is the most simple, mostly because it's the first DLC and was released during early access, and is less ambitious than the other 3 DLCs. However, it is still one of the best. It includes a lot of unique creatures, more than quite a few other maps, and new mechanics, such as wind speed for energy generating turbines, a creature that detects the weather for you so you won't be caught in the middle of a sandstorm or heatwave, a brand new structure that can defend you against the harsh sunlight, and new weapons such as flame arrows, flamethrowers, and the boomerang. Overall, I usually play Scorched Earth the most, and will pick it over The Island any day.

Aberration
My second favorite map and second favorite mechanics, it is one of the most stark changes with other maps, compared to the ones that came before it. It includes a smaller amount of creatures, but more unique abilities for each creature as a result, it also includes more unique systems, such as sunlight damage in the fertile and "safest" area of the map, the Nameless that will attack you if you venture too far into the Bioluminescent and Element biomes, and the unique Surface biome that can only be explored at night. It introduces new weapons and tools such as the climbing picks, ziplines, and the new Tek Railgun, which can shoot through walls. Overall, a very decent DLC and map with very unique changes than other maps that come along in the future, and one of the more challenging experiences.

Extinction
While a lot smaller in scale than the other two, it has my favorite atmosphere, and a very beautiful map in that dystopian sort of way. It has the least amount of new creatures so far, and a smaller variety of weapons and tools, but the map itself is quite enjoyable, in my opinion. It is split into Sanctuary, the safest biome in the map, the Desert and Tundra domes, and the Sunken Forest, all 3 reflecting more typical ARK biomes, and the only places you will find non-corrupted creatures, as the Wasteland is plagued with creatures corrupted by Element. It is not recommended to build anywhere in the Wasteland, as the corrupted creatures can destroy any building, including Tek structures You can also legitimately tame the 3 bosses it offers known as Titans, a completely unique feature than any other map. Overall, it's one of the more dangerous maps, like Aberration, but is more meant to be played with a max level character you have transferred from other maps, starting a new character in Extinction is clear that it is not the intended idea.

Genesis Pt. 1
The only DLC I haven't bought, and from what I've seen, the least like a survival game. It is more akin to an MMO, per se, and has a tiny selection of new creatures, and flying or flying creatures are strictly banned from its map, which forces you to use the new Bloodstalker or Astrocetus to fly in any way shape or form, or the new Tek Hovercraft. It is also extremely buggy, having cases such as rubberbanding, jittery gameplay, and overall it isn't very polished as of yet. You also have a new system, Hexagons and the store, which lets you buy materials with Hexagons, completely disregarding the survival aspect. Since it also costs $34.99 in US dollars for a single map, it is not a very good deal. It also seems like Pt. 2 will be it's own season pass as well? Overall, it's not very worth it, unless you really adore the map and its mechanics or want to learn more about the game's lore yourself.

Free DLC maps
These are technically fan mods that have been elevated as mini DLCs due to their popularity. In my opinion, they are all great, and each has 1 unique creature, except The Center, and a lot of unique bosses.

The Center: Includes no unique creatures, but includes a boss arena with all 3 of the Island's bosses in a single arena.

Ragnarok: Includes the Griffin, Ice Wyverns, Iceworm Queen [boss], and Lava Elemental [boss]

Valguero: Includes the Deinonychus, Chalk Golem, and Ice Golem.

Crystal Isles: Includes the Crystal Wyverns [Tropical, Blood, and Ember], Tropegnathus, and the Blood Wyvern Queen [boss]

ARK: Survival Evolved is far from a polished and perfect experience, but when it gets down to it, it is one of the better survival games, and the DLCs may be expensive, but for the full package and some of the more enjoyable maps, it is worth it to an extent. I hope this helped give a brief description of all the DLCs and the main game itself, even if I left out some details.

I awoke to find myself being stalked by a T-Rex...  Nothing but the clothes on my back, I ran for my life.  Everywhere I turned, I found massive beasts, some just lumbering along, ignoring me, and some looking to eat me for lunch.  Two Carnotaurus' chased me, fortunately, they are not too bright, and I ran around a really big rock, and they seemed to have lost my scent.  I ran, a lot!  Stayed alive for a while.  Made a small box, put some  things I thought I'd need for later.  It got dark.  I huddled in fear.  This was my first day.  Not a great day, but I lived!!

Days later, I found a friend...of a friend.  Friends are almost a necessity, if you want to survive...  I'd like to say I didn't die much before that, but I'd be lying.  Something jumped out of the ground and ate me, before I could run away.   A Carnotaurus that was a little smarter than the others chased me down, and ate me...

My friend took me in, kept me warm, killed stuff that wanted to eat me...again!  I built my own base, tamed a few dinos, and was on my way to actually living for a few days!!

That was about 6 months ago...  I run up to Rexes now, and laughingly cut them to ribbons with an awesome sword I found in a drop pod around Christmas, while they Roar.  They usually don't get to finish!  I've built quite a nice base, leveled up beyond my wildest dreams, and the only thing I still fear is a random Giganotosaur, though the three Auto Turrets on my roof, and my 6 or 7 tamed Rexes could probably kill one...

This is my favorite game, currently!  Yes, I have to log in every few days to feed my gaggle of awesome Tamed Dinosaurs, no matter what.  Yes, it can be time consuming to do things early on, it is a tad bit grindy.  Having a Tribe with friends is VERY helpful.

I am a big fan of survival-style games, and this is superb!  I'm currently playing on the Valguero map, but I've also played a few others, and love the size, variation of terrain and dinos, and practically endless gameplay challenges.  If they have the opportunity to try it, take that opportunity!  If you like it a little, I'm rather confident you'll like it A LOT!!!  I know I sure do!  And if you see me riding Freddie around Valguero (yes, my Therizinosaur, she's my favorite dino), say hi, I'll keep you alive...unless you're being chased by a Giga, then I'm out, and you're lunch!!

Edit: After more than a year of playing on the same server, this is still an awesome game, but for one little thing...  If you have a life outside of gaming, DO NOT PLAY ON OFFICIAL SERVERS!  50+ Dinos, including my beloved Freddie, mentioned above, have been DELETED by the official server because none of my three tribe members logged in within 7 days...8 days, and you lose.  If you've ever lost a pet, imagine playing a game with about 50 of them, only to have the game developers kick you in the groin and kill all of your pets in one unnecessary swipe.  Not because they starved to death, not because they were killed by a ferocious opponent, but because your life sucked for 7 days, and you couldn't find the time to log in to their game.  More than a year of work gone.  More than 50 of my virtual friends gone, instantly, and without a hope of recovery.  If I wanted this sort of experience, I'd spend more time in life, rather than in a game that's supposed to be fun...  I'm still recommending this game, as I've loved it, and the dinos I've come to know.  But the bastard developers who set an arbitrary deadline, and then kill all of your irreplaceable "pets", can jump from a moving Quetzel, without a parachute, over lava!!!!

as someone that has always wanted to play this game since it's alpha, it's very disappointing to find out that this game is as bare bones as it can get, and is reminiscent of horrible and unfair minecraft mods that spam overpowered enemies everywhere that you cannot avoid. there's literally hostile dinosaurs everywhere you look in this game and it honestly looks so corny to see them as often and in the abundance that you do. i ended up just treating it as a running gag and laughing anytime i turn around and see the 50th t-rex of the day charging at me to eat me.

i can't count the number of times i've been spawnkilled by dinosaurs that i thought were going to be super rare (tyrannosaurus, spinosaurus, sarcosuchus, etc.) in the early days of the game. i've once saw 3 spinosaurus crowded around each other at the same time. you can hardly ever get to your stuff without being killed once or twice along the way. sometimes the game doesn't even give you a marker where you died and you end up wanting to pull your hair out because you need to start over what is an incredibly tedious and delicate process. even after you manage to build a small base and a campfire to cook food like i did, you'll be disappointed to find out you can't build a permanent spawn point until level 7, and even when you unlock it, it takes a ton of hide to make, meaning you need to search for the 2-3 tiny harmless animals to kill over and over that are for some reason more rare than giant hostile dinosaurs for the hide you need, not to mention the other 4 materials you need a lot of...just to make a permanent spawn point at your base that you can respawn at over and over again when you die over and over again.

it's just not worth it to me. the game lost all it's glamor for me when i realized that nothing i ever discover in this game will ever be any cool because everything spawns everywhere, and leveling up again and again just to put up a fight against the weakest of enemies, let alone the giant ones that constantly attack you, just isn't worth the time or effort when there really isn't any reason to try. the game expends all of it's content too quickly, and in a poor fashion.
It's pretty bad. But unique and hits the spot on this type of genre.

Background: I've only played Ark as a single-person PvE sandbox game.

Do I recommend it: Yes, especially if you intend to play multi-player.

The Good: Ark is a masterfully-crafted game, with simple and excellently-balanced mechanics, and a massive amount of content.  The potential play time from Ark's map dwarfs all procedurally-generated worlds I've seen.

The Warning: AFAIK, Ark does not adjust its mechanics for the number of players.  Playing alone is literally akin to trying to survive alone on a predator-infested island.  You can be eaten at almost any time, you will need to tackle an ever-increasing workload to maintain yourself and your pets, and some tasks are just flat beyond the reach of one player.

Peeves:  These are minor nits I have with the game itself, less advice on buying it.
- The abundance of maintenance tasks in Ark is a key part of game balance, but it definitely appears keyed to challenge elite multiplayer tribes.  Would be nice if it were adjustable (it may be, but I can't find the setting.)
- The game uses a fun theme of "survivor with a journal", but the journal only covers a few topics.  Key concepts like how to gather resources pretty much require searching the wiki.  While the wiki is excellent, I personally like it if basic data is presented in-game.
- New animals get added to the game over time.  While it sounds like a neat idea, it's gradually adding acute and chronic challenge to the game:  acute, because of waking up to find a new toothy predator standing over you after an update, and chronic, because the island is running out of "safe" space.

So my previous review was false, it was indeed my issue and discovered what was causing it. So when you update ark, it makes a copy of it, which is...atrocious to say the least. The game is huge. So what'll happen is, if you don't have enough space on your SSD but have enough on an HDD it'll copy it over there. This creates a problem where it's constantly download to the HDD and then copying back over to the SSD. Even just having it downloaded on an HDD and staying there is faster. 

So, with that out of the way lets review the actual game. I will be 100% honest, I'm a PvE carebear, and mostly unofficial. That said I've played with a variety mods, no mods, rates etc. About 1500 hours is with no mods low rates (2x gathering, 5x breeding/incubation, 0.25 mating interval and 1x exp). It was a phenomenal community that is no longer existent. I've met a great friend there though, and that was almost 4 years ago and we're still friends and talk near daily to this day. We still go back to Ark and I won't tribe up with anyone else. I'd rather be solo than with anyone.

The actual game play is great. It's not perfect, it has bugs, but they aren't game breaking. The game is intensive on your system, and the story is interesting. You can make the game as fast as you want or slow, you can play PvP or PvE, total conversion mods or no mods. You make the game how you want. The maps are huge and anyone who says otherwise is playing on a flyer, and possibly with higher speed (mods). Ragnarok, Crystal Isles and Valguero especially are huge. They're all free maps too. I prefer the Island, it's very full, and every environment feels unique. While not the biggest, it doesn't feel as empty as Ragnarok or Crystal Isles does. 

I would go into this game with a mindset that it's not going to be flawless, but you can lose hours and days here. Maybe even weeks. If you're looking for something to do for days on end, this game is a great way to spend it. It's hard for me to get back into it, but I do play it every now and then and love it all the same. I know so much that I can accelerate my play speed ten fold than what I did when I was new. The learning curve is large, but I always followed a philosophy. Don't take what you can't afford to lose out of your base. Items, Dinos, etc.

Enjoy, this game is a great one. Not a master piece, but there are far worse survival games.

Here's the rub: 
If you try to play ark on an official server, you might as well not bother. 
If you're playing single player or on a non-dedicated server, it's fantastic. (Although it's WAY better with friends!)

I set up a non-dedicated server (2, actually, one each for the Island and the Center, and I'm going to add Ragnarok and Scorched Earth shortly) and played with a some buddies, and it was fantastic. It's still challenging to deal with the random dinos that rip you to pieces but you don't have to deal with the jerks that play on official servers and wreck anyone who tries to do anything. There's the satisfaction of building a base and leveling up and getting stuff done and TAMING DINOS, for heaven's sake. How much better could it get?! It's not even that hard to set up a non-dedicated server. If you want help doing it, let me know and I'll walk you through it.

If you don't like to grind every now and then and just want to PvP, either stick to the official servers (good luck) or play Survivial of the Fittest instead.

Edit 8-23-20:
I'm up to 950 hours of game time, and this is still an awesome game for all of the above reasons. Definitely one of my favorites ever. I haven't gotten the Genesis DLC yet, but given how much content there is between The Island and Extinction, combined with the free DLC maps, I'm in no hurry to get it, and I don't have tons of time to play anyway. Still playing primarily on my personal dedicated server (which I run on the same machine I play the game on). Tons of fun playing with friends whenever our schedules align.

While I do recommend giving this game a try if you are a masochist I will say that I really wish the devs game the combat an overhaul.

Currently the game revolves around taking 10 guys to a dino, trapping it in a man made cage/wall/fence and then shooting it with tranq arrows/darts until after 100's of shots it finally falls asleep, then it takes hours to feed it and wake it up tamed in your tribes name.

I don't like that.

Two solutions, the first would not require many changes, they would just have to make the game more balanced around solo/duo torpor/damage/resistances and attack/movement speeds. I would recommend they look at some videos of Darkfall / Darkfall Unholy Wars for Inspirations on proper PVE and PVP Gameplay.

Route 2 would be an overhaul of the combat system to work more like Darksouls so that each monster has a move set so you can dodge/block/parry/do some move to counter the moves of the dinos, they can add some randomness to it when it comes to the choice of move the dino does but since there are hundreds of dinos remembering which moveset to dodge each dino will bring a level of mastery to the game easy to learn difficult to master, instead  of its current meta of difficult to learn, very difficult to master.

Anyways I got some good time out of this game but I am having to mod the fuck out of it to continue to play it without going insane with the unbalance and grind and waiting around.

Take this review with a grain of salt since I've only been able to play for nearly 20 hours.  Before I even get into the gameplay, I'll talk about the straw that broke the camel's back - the sheer amount of storage space that this game consumes.  Don't let the download screen fool you - this game is well over 100GB in size when extracted.  Even worse, each new update adds 10+GBs of content.  With the way the game looks, it's actually insane that it consumes this much space.  The textures do not look all that great and I'm speaking lightly.  Either way, I had attempted to play this game after some time away, when an update completely filled my download cache and destination drive.  Even after clearing out unplayed games, it was still too big to fit in either drive.  It was this point, after the latest update pushed my drive to its limit, that I uninstalled.

Secondly, the game is optimized so poorly that my 1080TI was struggling to run it on High settings.  The game does NOT look good enough to warrant my PC heating up my apartment by another 10 degrees.  It is actually ridiculous how much of a lack of concern the devs have with your ability to run this game.  Once they sell it to you with the shiny wrapper and promise of having the dino army of your dreams, you're practically dead to them.  Mission accomplished.
  
But none of that is really my main gripe.  You could get past these issues for sure.  But no, my real issue is the gameplay, which to me is most important.  First of all, I'm not sure how this game gets away with forcing the player to spend so much time performing mundane tasks that get subsequently punished by the plethora of bugs and RNG litterred throughout the game.  Did you just spend several hours obtaining the dino you wanted?  Have a small army of dinos at your disposal?  Trained your dinos to be stronger and faster than your average dino?  Great!  Watch as a few unlucky spawns result in an aerial raid that swoops in and leaves your army and co-op partners in ruins!

To put it in perspective, after playing this once with some friends the very first time, we managed to do the following:

* Crafted some decent weapons and a nice cache of supplies
* Tamed some low level dinos
* Tamed a few tankier mid level dinos
* Built a 2 story base of operations
* Built a wall around our base (it was in progress at the time of the attack below)
* Assembled armor of decent quality and mid tier ranged weaponry

This equated to about... 10+ hours of work for me alone.  And most of it was coordinated by my tribe mates while I had already logged off for the night.  Note that I use the word "work" with FULL intention here - all of these tasks were a slog and did not hold any innate entertainment value.  One of my least favorite chores was dino taming, which required that we babysit the dinos we wanted to tame while we periodically force fed them berrires/meats.  

Anywho, once all the work was done, we could finally start getting into the groove and have a little fun exploring.  We had dinos to ride and fly around on.  Our base was on the peak of a hill overlooking the landscape.  It was reasonably well fortified.  We had a pretty darn good foundation and were ready to set out... until a TRex-lookin' dino that spawned meters away from our camp, decided it hated our tribe and everything we stood for.  A few grueling minutes and several futile deaths later, the damage was done.  Might as well have slapped a game over sign on the screen right then and there. 

So what was the damage exactly?  Most of us permanently lost our gear because we couldn't find it amidst the slaughter.  One person's gear clipped through the terrain.  All of our dinos, sans one tiny little guy who actually listened to our orders to stay in the base, were slaughtered mercilessly.  The TRex had left its mark all over the battlefield in the form of feces carrying the DNA of our lost reptilian brethren.  Needless to say, that was a hard stop to the barely existent enjoyment elicited by this game.

I've tried to get started in this game twice since then, and have had similar experiences both times, though not nearly at the same scale.  I think I can safely say that if you are the sort of person who appreciates saving your money for years only to have some lowlife dip steal your identity and make off with it all, you would absolutely love this game!  I for one, in my barely sane mind, do not.  

To be fair, perhaps the hardcore survival game enthusiast would appreciate how rough this game is.  Though the lack of polish and care would grate on even the most avid of survival fans.  I thought I was included in their ranks, but clearly, after playing Ark, I discovered the limits of what I could survive.  Godspeed to all those who long for Ark's unique brand of suffering.  

P.S. In the spirit of fairness, yes, you can turn down the more grindy elements in the game if you start your own server.  Did it matter that much when we tried it?  Not really.  Just meant that our inevitable loss hurt that much less when it happened.  But it was still time wasted, no matter how you slice it.  With that said, cheers to you, Ark - a complete waste of 20 hours of my life.

I probably actually have at least a thousand hours on Ark since I started off on Xbox. It certainly has its problems, and it will make you rage at times because despite the fact that it's sometimes broken, it delivers an amazingly rewarding gameplay loop and hooks you quickly. It has a steep learning curve for higher level play, so definitely don't try to take on an official server alpha tribe as a new player or anything. Steam's version is the best way to play, with mods giving the game SO much more quality of life. Vanilla Ark, especially on Official, can get REALLY grindy, with a lot of "chores" to do. Finding a server with the right rates for you is the hardest part, IMO. But once you find the sweet spot, you'll be immensely addicted. Don't play if you can't devote reasonable time to it because when you log out, your character stays where it's at (and your stuff does, too). If you're not in a safe area, you're in danger when you're logged out. Group play with reasonable time dedication is the most rewarding experience. If you get paranoid easily, Ark PvP may not be for you. On PvP servers, you have to automate base defenses or hide, because when you log off, other players may try to destroy your base and take your stuff. Paranoia can run rampant at higher level play. But if you're not deterred by this, Ark will definitely be worth it. I'll put it squarely in my top 10 favorite games of all time.

I have played single player only (custom server settings).  I have no recommendations for PVE/PVP server play.

TLDR - I would recommend this game and the DLC content.  Fun, challenging with a high replayability. 

Lots of game settings to adjust difficulty and grinding (level, stat gain, harvest, dino stats, breeding, etc).  Some of these are simple and intuitive and others need to be researched.  Between the wiki, youtube content creators, and some trial and error I was able to come up with settings that worked for me.

The one issue I have with the game is the building.  It is frustrating with placement limitations and the limited time (30 sec) to pick up placed items. I solved most of these issues with S+ Mod. 

One feature I would like to see is a way to adjust spawn types, rates, max levels, and level weight (IE higher level spawns more common).  I know some of this can be accomplished by modifying the ini files but it is difficult for non tech people to do.

This game has a very steep learning curve, but with that being said this game offers so much it is a no brainer it is worth the time and effort to learn how to play and survive! Ark is what a survival game should feel like. The mechanics are spot on and there is so much to do other than just survive. Highly recommend to anyone looking for a solid rpg/survival game to play.

Yikes!. £45 game with £75 of DLC. While it looks very impressive and has a lot of content. Do not underestimate the volume of bugs when players interact with the world.

The player gets stuck on the dinos, the dinos get stuck on the buildings, the players cant get on the raft, the raft gets stuck on the beach, the rocks clip through the raft and swipe the dinos into the sea. 

5+ years of development and it's still a joke to play because of this, yet the devs add new bugs and DLC and totally overlook these issues.

This should have never left the Alpha status until it was smooth to play. It looks and runs well enough, but that alone does cut it and justify the cost. 

It is a £15 mediocre game at best at present, and I hope for a lot more from it. 

Am happy I only spent £20 on it.

The game is amazing, but at the end of the day it ends up feeling like a job. Once you get a big enough base and put a few turrets up to defend your base, You cant leave the game or some douche bag with riot gear and c4 comes and kills everything  and steals everything you have worked hard for. You end up playing this game for 6 hours doing one meaningless task like leveling up ur anky so you can get more metal in one run, and you come back to your base being watched every minute of your time in the game. And then there's that one guy waiting hours possibly days for you to log off so he can take all the progress from you. If you want to play this game, i HIGHLY suggest playing PvE unless you like the excruciating pain of Loss from everything you have worked for. The fan base can be Very toxic in PvP. Reviews shouldn't be about  the looks of the game, it should be about the game. But, while i enjoyed the game, i didnt enjoy many parts of it. Still better than fortnite.

Probably don't use the default settings. You'll spawn, get killed immediately and repeat until you want to throw something. Google how to tweak the game settings for an easier start, then once you get the hang of it, you can tweak the settings again to make it more interesting.

Cross-play with the Epic version requires the server to run NO MODS (as of 8-20-20), so if you're having issues finding the server in Epic, that could be why. There are other possible connection issues, but they have workarounds.

Taming enormous creatures is a nice payoff for the amount of work you put into the process and some can be extremely valuable in base-building since they can harvest resources for you. (Gigantopithecus gathers more fiber than you'll ever use. Doedicurus gathers a lot of stone.)

Given the difficulty of playing PvE under normal settings, I've never tried playing on a public server with PvP. I can imagine that it would be an awful experience given how much grief I get in other games.

Game is awesome, the content is great.  If there is a con, it's this; there isn't a word in any language on Earth that can truly describe the update time for this game.  It doesn't matter how big or small the update is.  I'm currently waiting on a 19mb update for about an hour now.

So I have almost 900 hrs played...

Why do I have given it a negative review? 

Because a lot of those 900hrs were doing things to try to play the game.

From the start... it took possibly 10-20 hrs just to find the right blend of settings between graphics/performance.

Possibly another 50 hrs is just waiting for the game to load, crash, try to reload again, crash... or getting kicked out for an update no one cares about, 5 mins again waiting to log back in... u go to a part of the map ur PC doesnt like? crash! 5 more mins trying to get back in. 

Now a lot of those crashes mean ur body died somewhere.... so u gotta spend more time looking for ur body... u might lose a mount that took u hrs to tame...

So when u put it all together I wouldnt be surprised if around 20-30% of my 900 hrs is just me TRYING to play the game, server t ime outs, servers not having updated, etc... 


Does this game have a good concept? yes thats why I almost spent 1000 hrs on it... (30% dealing w issues) 

But during most of that time I was thinking: "WHAT AN AWESOME GAME! I am sure the devs will fix this, or that soon".... years later is now clear that will probably never happen.

If the Devs showed the intent to fix these things then I would be playing and giving it a positive review... but as that doesnt seem to be part of their schedule then its a no from me...

I will gladly change it to a Positive if things get better... but why do that when you can just make another DLC, right?? 

Yeah, if you are new, thats Ark's business model... "Cover the turds with glitter"...  turds being the bugs and the glitter being the dlc.

I want to preface this by stating that if I could give a "Neutral" rating, I would. As whilst the game, for the most part is a decent survival game with many a funny moment when playing with friends, it has its down sides.

ARK, with friends, is fun. LOTS of fun. Running around a beach, naked, beating animals with rocks whilst making stupid jokes with your friends, what more can ya want? 
There's a lot of satisfaction going from essentially a cave-man to being a high-tech super warrior riding a robot T-Rex. 

But playing the game solo? The silence is DEAFENING. Any sounds, be it from friend or foe, are a startling welcome as you struggle to get out of the mud of poverty stricken neanderthal era technology.

On top of this, you have the obvious problems under the hood. This game EATS your computer. I run a fairly decent specs computer that I maintain on a regular basis and this game just looks at it like an Asian kid's father whom just saw his son bring home a B in Science.

Do I like ARK? Yes. Would I recommend it to friends? Absolutely. But for selfish purposes. I need them if I'm to ever return to this game.

It's been a while since my last review, and my last one was made when I was quite the belligerent type. 

The game is decent. It is horribly optimized and there is almost no way for low end pc's to run this game, but if your specs can run it, then have all the fun you can. I recommend playing on modded servers, because I've tried playing on official servers and it's honestly way too time consuming. It takes a week to tame a Giga and then when you tame one, its stats get cut right in two, whereas on a modded server, it may take you up to 30 minutes, an hour if you're unlucky. Flyers are also really bad on official. They had nerfed them at some point to where you cant up their speed, so you may as well ride a turtle on land instead of riding a pterra. Also make sure you have friends to play with. Bases are hard to manage on solo and mats are much easier to grab with people. Also, watch out for compies (I think that's how you spell their name) and sharks. They can come out of nowhere and can shred your gear and dinos in seconds, weather it be on modded or official.

I've played MMORPGs, ARPGs, and online games my entire life. Ark is one of the most ambitious and content heavy games I've ever seen. Sure, it has balance issues. It has some performance issues (which have gotten better over time). 

Ark is a survival game, pvp game, and dino breeding/taming game. It has a full story, deep end game progressive and bosses as well as a large community and learning curve.

I recommend staying away from official servers which are excessively grindy, and easily abused by "Alpha Tribes" if you are new. 

If you are new to survival games, understand they can be very frustrating at first and until you get some good gear/dinos on this game it will feel very hard and unforgiving. Big learning curve here.

I love this game. I really do, and I think it has so much potential. It looks amazing and has so many awesome mechanics that have never been included in any other game I’ve played. Normally, I would strongly recommend everyone to give it a go. The key word there being normally.

However, I’ve also never encountered a game that throws as many tantrums as this one does. I’ve gotten through two laptops and a desktop trying to play, both laptops were killed off by overheating, the second laptop was gone before it’s one year warranty was done. The desktop lost the functioning of it’s NVIDIA graphics card to this titan and I had to do a system reset to before I’d even installed the game. Speaking of installing, you’d better have ~150gb spare on an SSD drive (HDD starts lagging uncontrollably the more you play) and each map will add on about 50gb. Some people occasionally get lucky and are able to play ARK on the equivalent of a potato, but once you start playing this game you won’t want to stop and I’m begging you to not sacrifice your life and your technology to Wildcards monstrosity. They seem to have decided that rather than fixing and utilizing their spaghetti-fied mess of code, they instead want to release DLC after DLC and bring you reskinned versions of old dinos with a few new gimmicks (I’m looking at you Tropeognathus). The point of games should be that they are able to be enjoyed by everyone without having to dedicate mass amounts of time troubleshooting why the game keeps crashing or why it runs at 10fps. There are more threads of people complaining about how bad the game runs than there are official servers in the game.

All in all I’ll give ARK credit for being so good that despite all of its many, many flaws people still want to play it, me included. But again- please do not sell your soul to a game that’s going to give you hell for your entire relationship with it. No amount of new dinos will make it worth the drain on your wallet, your time and your patience. Wildcard, please figure out if you want ARK to become a cult classic with as much replayability as something like Skyrim, or if you want to fade into obscurity because you spent all your time making quick cash grab DLC maps that are even more badly functioning than the core game.

Are you looking for a survival game?  Are you looking for a survival game with MO'FKIN' DINOSAURS!?

Then move along.  I've clocked in almost 1k hours and nearly 100 in the last couple week and I can confidently say the game is still the massive dumpster fire it was always destined to be(I mean, c'mon.  The CEO plagiarized another Dev's idea and also broke his non-compete clause.  What more can you expect from a showrunner who's IQ obviously isn't breaking double digits?)

Russian/Chinese zergs are still a thing on public servers, the latest FreeLC map is a buggy pile of garbage, and via dark wizardry or some shit; the AI has gotten worse, not better.

For those coming back: Just imagine your original experience, but your tames are even more likely to fuck about than they used to, ESPECIALLY flyers.  I died, respawned, and watched my argentavis struggle to kill a microraptor for 10~ minutes before I got bored(read: finished my cig).  I'm not even going to touch on the shitty hitboxes, either, because they've gone into the dumpster fire, too.

For those new to the game: Ark is an early-access 20$~ game, trying to sell itself as a 50$ full release(145$ if you buy the season pass+DLC, which is a fuckin' joke, btw).

Seriously, just stay away, that's my best advice.  Everything Ark does well gets mired by buggy crap that'll either A). Kill you,  B). Kill your Dinos, or C). Both.

Oh, say can you see by the dawn’s early light
What so proudly we hailed at the twilight’s last gleaming?
Whose broad stripes and bright stars thru the perilous fight,
O’er the ramparts we watched were so gallantly streaming?
And the rocket’s red glare, the bombs bursting in air,
Gave proof through the night that our flag was still there.
Oh, say does that star-spangled banner yet wave
O’er the land of the free and the home of the brave?

On the shore, dimly seen through the mists of the deep,
Where the foe’s haughty host in dread silence reposes,
What is that which the breeze, o’er the towering steep,
As it fitfully blows, half conceals, half discloses?
Now it catches the gleam of the morning’s first beam,
In full glory reflected now shines in the stream:
‘Tis the star-spangled banner! Oh long may it wave
O’er the land of the free and the home of the brave!

And where is that band who so vauntingly swore
That the havoc of war and the battle’s confusion,
A home and a country should leave us no more!
Their blood has washed out their foul footsteps’ pollution.
No refuge could save the hireling and slave
From the terror of flight, or the gloom of the grave:
And the star-spangled banner in triumph doth wave
O’er the land of the free and the home of the brave!

Oh! thus be it ever, when freemen shall stand
Between their loved home and the war’s desolation!
Blest with victory and peace, may the heav’n rescued land
Praise the Power that hath made and preserved us a nation.
Then conquer we must, when our cause it is just,
And this be our motto: “In God is our trust.”
And the star-spangled banner in triumph shall wave
O’er the land of the free and the home of the brave

When I’m having a good time in ARK, I’m having a really good time. The problem is that those moments are usually one part to every nine parts menial grinding and crafting - especially at the later tech tiers. Having to repeat so much work after failing an attempt at a boss feels far too punishing, and some really dumb dinosaurs can take a lot of the challenge and sense of danger out of the many primal locations. Even with all of those quirks, however, I’m still hungry to play more after the 68 hours I’ve spent so far. There aren’t a lot of survival games that have legitimately held my attention that long.

Creative, Imaginative, Daring, Expansive.

These are the words I would use to describe this game. At a mere 90 hrs of gameplay that pales in comparison to fellow players who have played this game for thousands of hours, this game has engrossed me fully with its gameplay. This game offers a pletora of flora and fauna species to be explored, tamed, bred and expanded in several biomes, maps, DLCs and events. This game feels like an MMO at times due to the amount of time you have to invest (and trust me, you will want to invest more time in it) Each animal has its utility, and each portion of the map opens to new posibilities of adventure, and a new thread on your tapestry of experiences you will enjoy in this game. Be warned, you will die, you will fail several times to tame your favorite dino, but with strategy and perseverance (and with the helping hand of more experienced players) you will survive, adapt and even overcome these maps

I installed this game quite a while ago, and it took most of a day to download and install. Once it installed, I played the game, and it wasn't worth the long wait. The game is built for multiplayer, and the single player mode is quite a chore. It's not particularly friendly for new players. You will most likely be unprepared for any threats that come your way, and it's a heck of a grind to get to the point you'll feel somewhat safe. I know, it's a survival game, but, in my opinion, it doesn't ease you in to it.

Of course, I didn't get to play it for long. One update took so long it wreaked havoc on my system and I couldn't do much of anything. So I got rid of it. Honestly, it's not worth the long download time, and not worth playing on single player.
