I keep getting sucked into this game, many hours at a time. Would recommend it for sure, but also beware, cause this game has a tendency to wake feelings of love AND hate towards it, because while hard work pays off usually, with just a fingersnap it can be all gone XD 
Usually when going into more challenging content or having a huge amount of misfortune ...like running into a ytyrannus, dino getting scared of it, dino runs in it's scaredness into a pack of wolves, running off a cliff with all those dinos after you into a dip of terrain, just so that when you die down there, it's almost impossible to retrieve your items XD.
Tip: always have backups in form of dinos and equipment, ready for retrieval actions, preferably throwaway dinos or very strong ones that can deal with almost anything like rexes XD.
It will save a lot of your sanity if you are also able to just "leave a lost body be" ...take only with you, what you really need for certain "missions"...

I love this game, have been playing it alot, with friends/without, pvp and pve and even on roleplay servers :) It has something for everyone....my favourite activities are taming and building by far ^^ also...go unofficial...even with improved rates on official, some mods are just amazing and the rates on unofficials are usually higher, less painful.

This game was probably my first major purchase on Steam. I bought it in 2017 (I think), while it was on sale for 40$. I was rather upset that at the time I didn't know that steam did a big sales event during the summer so the week later, it was on sale for 20. besides that, the game has an amazing theme and great aspirations and meets them to certain extents... however I would be remiss if I didn't mention the downfalls of the game. I first tried to play it on my mac book pro 2012, and I know it was my fault for trying to play it on a computer that couldn't handle it but a few years later I got a much much nicer PC that could play much more complex games and yet it would still crash. I had to play with the settings a bit and lower the quality of the graphics to be able to run it at a smooth 60 fps. For a game that promises so much, I'm rather disappointed to find that it didn't have to power to show me its true extent. The game is still fun to play but needs fixing. 7.2/10

3 months later and i now have mixed feelings. 5/10

I Enjoy this game when its functioning and it has a really solid concept, great art, and it can be a lot of fun. The problem the whole game and company sits on an attitude of absolute disregard for the player. Their game is designed to force you to perform massive grinds to build up your base and get your dinosaurs only to flippantly destroy what you built when one of the endless number of bugs pops up. The servers often go down for hours or days and a lot of the time the game is running on that server with no players. This means that the large quantities of dinosaurs you've spent hours taming or raising from babies will die of starvation while you stare helplessly at a login screen. These babies take 9-18 hours of hand feeding with constant attention to raise followed by days of having to login every 8 hours to make sure they have the best stats only to have their terrible servers take it all away. In addition it seems no one at the company is actually paying attention to whats happening in their game or servers and bug reports are completely ignored. A recent patch note claimed they changed a timer on a boss fight from 20 minutes to 30 minutes... no they didn't, and whats more even after i reported it the false patch notes remain live and have been for three weeks. They fundamentally don't care about your experience or time.

Another great example, on extinction they decided it would be a great idea to have a map border which when you crossed it you would die and lose everything including your steed. In addition that server often has massive minute long spikes in lag where you can accidentally fly off the map. Finally, one of the banner creatures for that map is one that "shoots" through the air and is the most prone to flying off the map. Putting it all together you have an absolute deathtrap that has existed for over a year and nobody thinks hey maybe we could be a little nicer to our players and not kill them when our server freaks out.

Examples of blatant disregard for player experience:
Valguero Manticure Bosses Glitch out and never land for you to fight, after 20 minutes game kills you and all your dinosaurs
Extinction Orbital Drops come down and murder you (no issue) and your dinosaurs you bred from babies with little to no warning.
Extinction edge kills you and your mount in a manner of seconds, even if server lag is what placed you outside the boundary
You have to login to "imprint" your dinos every 8 hours of you don't get full stats, try having a job or sleeping at night with this requirement
Raising babies takes 2-14 days and requires constant care every single day or they die and waste all that progress

Clearly I've invested in this game but i wouldn't recommend others do it. While it has moments which are amazing the way the company deals with its player base is the most toxic i've ever seen.

I play this game, only because a friend enjoys it. 

I believe it is riddled with too many bugs or glitches as well as poor game mechanics, creature and structure designs. 

Despite having great internet and computer specs far past the ideal requirements to play the game, it still regularly lags or hiccups, even when simply walking around. 

I have gotten stuck on rocks/boulders, jumped into a lake and fell halfway through the ground so I could still move and see under water but ended up drowning cause I couldn't escape the lake floor. 

Taming is a joke. it is almost as if the game actively tries to fuck over any attempts at taming. I have been in an area that had no predators, the entire time i played, and the moment I start taming something multiple appear? and that happens a lot it wasn't a one time occurrence; or i walk away from the tame and the unconsciousness level rapidly disappears at a rate faster than when I was standing by it. 

When building, it often doesn't place a mat or structure where I intended it to be, or even where it was highlighted as being. Also, when placing items close together, such as storage cabinets, one minute you can put them nearly inside each other while other times you have to have a decent gap between them. They have horrible consistency with the collision or physical boundaries of various structure. 

There is a similar issue with domesticated dinos and their movement or attack patterns. One minute it is smooth sailing, you can walk through trees that clearly are too close to fit a dino through, but then a small rock or boulder will stop a freaking rex in its tracks. As far as attacking with dinos, while mounted it is a joke, you are better off letting them attack without you, because when you are riding them, they seem to have the turning radius of a tractor and trailer, while unmounted they have the flexibility of a gymnast and can bite an opponent when not even facing them somehow. lol However, a minute later, while you are being molested by a wild dino, your dino, especially flying ones, will take forever attacking them, often needing to fly far away to come back for an attack, when seconds ago they were doing donuts around another dino, biting it contantly. 

To be honest, this game, which they are asking way to much for, IMHO, feels like it would be a game that was barely in alpha, if that makes any sense. They have WAY too many problems to be selling this as an essentially completed game, especially for their price.  I will not recommend this to anyone and believe the devs should be ashamed of their work, as it stands. 

I will not be replying to comments, as this is primarily a means of venting my frustration with the game, not wishing for continued discourse about the game.

This game has had potential since the beginning. It's been 5 years since it first came out (in beta) and it still hasn't reached it's full potential. It is borderline unplayable. Certain things about the game give me joy (animal taming and riding them) but they still don't make up for how poorly prioritized it is. Even some of the best gaming PC's struggle to run it. For what reason... I have no idea. It isnt just how the game runs it's also some of the game mechanics. dying on the other side of the map for some stupid reason, then having to tame a new pteranodon and fly there just for my loot to have despawned is not how I want to spend 3 hours of my day. Another thing that is entirely broken and needs to be fixed is the no-clip. It is so bullshit that someone can just sit outside my metal base and chomp me through the wall with their t-rex. If you think this game is good because of a couple youtubers you watch play it, you are horribly wrong. If it isn't below $10 or free don't buy this game, Just play a different survival game or even use minecraft dinosaur mods for all I care.

This game is like a B-Movie night with friends. Playing alone can be frustrating and terribad, especially with the impossible PVP in the game. But with friends, this game brings endless amounts of shenanigans and laughter. Definitely a game that's worth playing with your significant other or group.

Ark is a fantastic game that has had plenty of content added to it. I'm not a fan of the company or the way they do busness. I picked up the game and the first 3 DLC for £20 after admiring it for ages. I've played it for an obscene amount in the relatively short time I've owned it. To me this game comes closer than many games to having it all. Its done more aspects of its gameplay well than many games I love. Sure its got flaws, Dino clipping is probably my most irritating flaw, but I feel like theres no easy option on how this should have been done given the staggering variety of creatures you can tame and their differing relative sizes. Im not a PVPer but it appeals to me that any/all Ark gameplay ive enjoyed could in theory have been done under a PVP framework. People moan about the PVP, sayings its not fit for purpose. Id just like to know what other games thas has even a vaguely similar gameplay/content loadout has  PVP baked in. Lets say Arks hit registering in PVP is bad. (I've never experienced this). What is better ? Also I imagine its pretty equal for all players.  Maybe the complaints stem from how good of  game ark is, its so game that people wish it was perfect. Well practically perfect will do for me. FInlly the building, I've probably spent more time in ark building than anything else. The building system is fantastic. It can be frustrating s hell for various reasons, but those reasons have a cause in my opinion (like dino clipping issues). The structures plus mod fixes many issues and takes arks excellent building system and improves it.

If theres one thing id like more of in ark, its item variety. Id like to see more loot in ark, more armour weapons and outfits, more structures to build. But even this, I suspect has been fairly heavily balanced and presents enough options to be interesting.

I forgive you ark all your minor faults while celebrating what I consider to be one of the finest gaming experiences ever created. Its peers as I know them do not come close. (maybe atlas one day if it doesnt die completely).

Are you a Dino-Fan? Do you love open and loveable Maps? are you in for Hours of frustration, because you are going to die in the beginning, over, and over, and over again? are you a Dino fan? do you love riding dinos? and building stuff? crafting weapons and go hunting? do you love dinos? than go grab this game. NOW!
You can tame dinosaurs, ride them and name them. That's about it though.

Mostly played on a private / friend server. And we modified the rules and settings to be more friendly to a small group for taming. Did not play public servers or PVP.

Premise: 9/10 - The idea super fun and rewarding. Its not the same old MMO or shooting game copying something else. Survival, crafting, while taming dinosaurs to ride with crazy tech ranging from bows to guns. Crazy entertaining.

Survival: 8/10 - Pretty damn hard/frustrating at times. Can die alot in the beginning while learning how to manage food/water and avoiding predators near your spawn. Can be frustrating and/or annoying dealing with some of the aspects like night time can fuck you when it sneaks up on you in a forest. Food/water can be annoying when you are trying to do something else. But its meant to have that and its not overly annoying, having a tame/dino mitigates that after a certain point. Fine and can be adjusted if needed (not public though).

Crafting: 7/10 - Not alot of thought process in the crafting tree. Pure level based crafting tree. But lots of crafting and things that are useful for various situations. You got all kinds of saddles to make, guns and weapons, crafting stations, quality of life stuff. Tooltips and information are decent enough to figure out. Could be better or more intuitive and the tree has room for improvement. Relocating resources can be a paing without mods. There are mods for many of those things though. Plenty to do crafting wise to have a nice big base for your needs. Mods to make them crazy castles and tree forts. 

Building: 6/10 - Yes you can build bases and what not, mostly everything is good. Some things are just frustrating lik enot being able to pick something up or having something snap on top of something else or being blocked or seeping through a wall. You can build, but nothing allows for true planning or expansion well, without mods.

Breeding/Taming: 9/10 - Come on you get to tame and ride T-Rexs. Taming in a real public server is probably a friggin nightmare. But basically you can tranq a dino, feed it, wait, repeat (depending on settings is time/effort) to ultimately tame/claim a dino to your army. Craft and throw a saddle on it and you can ride it. So much fun and very rewarding just murdering shit with some super predator. Then if you want you can mate/breed them to get better stats. Some of the default settings are kinda harsh and grindy, but meant for big server clan type stuff. There is alot going on here that can keep you busy for along while, even with super taming/breeding speeds. Have had farms of T-Rexs, Argies, Kangaroos, etc just to try and get better ones.

Content/Maps: 7/10 - Content is very basic and not much to do other than some boss fights which are limited in arenas. Personally feel like its a weak attempt at progression. The maps are huge and generally fun to explore, few of them have seen almost every inch of them and are fun to build in on and explore. They also have "crystal beams" which are bascially random loot crates to help with gearing up. Not a fun or rewarding experience, just disappointing most of the time. Loot can be annoying to progress through. You will spend most of your time getting your tames/bases built up. Again, on a real server the experience is PVP and staying alive.

PVP: N/A

Overall: 8/10 - Liked this game. Play with friends. Pay for a server. Tame some dinos. Build a base. Get murdered alot at night. Fun times.

Note: Developers/publishers are kinda trash. They could make this game SO MUCH BETTER. They have had legal problems. They haven't fixed some very basic bugs that cause alot of frustration. They haven't really made any key changes to take any step further. Instead they money grab. So if you have a problem with that, dont support them.

I'd been wanting to get into this for a while now, and now that it's on sale thought "hey, why not buy it."
Big mistake. Not only is it a buggy mess,  beginning is a nightmare. Spawn system seems to teleport you further and further away from where you die each time, and has no regard for if there's a building or /aggressive creatures/ right on top of you. Most of my deaths were followed by second and third deaths because of unlucky spawns next to direwolves and raptors.

Not only that, but for some reason temperatures will screw you over. Too hot? Shade won't help, unless it's a structure you've built. That includes four walls and a roof. Too cold? Torches and campfires are your friend, but /only if you're inside a building/. That's right, holding an actual flaming log two inches from your face doesn't count as "heat" unless you've got a bit of thatch over your head.

And the combat! Good god at the camera shake when firing a spear or slingshot. It's like a constant earthquake. And if anything's above level 5? Good luck. Troodons will take one bite out of you and knock you out within seconds. And they're /tiny/. Hell, three Compy'sll screw your day over. Y'know, those tiny, smaller than chickens dinos from jurrassic park? Three. Not the pack of ten or so taking on a little 9 year old girl. Three teeny tiny two-legged rats with a temper problem, vs an extreme bodybuilding, possibly genetically engineered human. Oh and punching anything barefisted kills you. Because reasons.

Edit: 8/9/2020
ALL OF THAT BEING SAID! I have put 233 hours into this game. It's still a buggy mess. It's still brutally difficult. Torpidity sucks. Multiplayer is ABSOLUTE trash. So why, after all this complaining, am I recommending this game? 
I learned the mechanics. The game absolutely lets you customize every setting to suit your playstyle. Missing features? There's probably a mod for that. And the actual diversity of creatures rivals any other dino game to my knowledge. This is one of those games you fully lose yourself in for days on days on days. Players beware, the cost of going back in time is losing most of your future to ARK.

Edit: 8/14/20
I remember why I stopped playing. The reason people have such high playtimes, and then not recommend it is because it's a poorly designed game which takes LITERAL IN REAL LIFE DAYS to accomplish basically anything. To even make it playable in singleplayer, you have to max out the options, and then download mods. "There's a mod for that" should be a phrase for if you want extra features like more furniture, or to have pokemon running around. It shouldn't be up to the modding community (which, my god, you guys are incredible) to fix broken mechanics and game-breaking bugs. I'd give suggestions on how to fix the game, but honestly, the only thing Wildcard listens to is it's bank account.

However ARK in its entirety is a massive investment, having payed nearly $300 AUD on ARK so far for often mediocre advancement for the player just looking for a base purchase the modded community (although it requires large amounts of storage) provides advancement and additions the Devs haven't provided realistically unless you are an extremely dedicated player looking for story, environment and small additions as I am myself there is no need to actually purchase season passes or additional payed DLCs. Hope my review helped either guide your purchase or draw you into this great game either way I hope you all enjoy your ARK experience :)

They simply keep releasing "new dinos" and many many of the GLARING issues go unaddressed. ARK has PVP and PVE both of them are an exploiters wet dream! On the "official" servers I have played on about 20 of them either a group of chinese run it or a group of rude players gains an advantage that newer players have no hope of overcoming and they are constantly tormented at level 1-30 to the point most of them quit. So then you seek out a moderated game environment. Great the game is still broken and they seem to release the WORST patches on fridays just in time to completely foul up your week end game play. 

Over the past month 3 out of 4 weekends have been spoiled by a lame patch rushed out the door and BAM you can't log in. All the hype from the youtubers is from lame non experienced gamers trying to boost their earning on youtube. If they were honest this alpha is NOT worth paying for. The Game runs on the Unreal Engine and they Devs seem to have problems adjusting the most basic of map settings so be prepared to spend 1/2 of your game time in an extremely bright glare filled environment being blinded by the sun, and the other 1/2 of your game time is spent in complete darkness where you are forced to carry a large bright come kill me beacon called a torch. You are promptly killed by someone that has figured out to alt-tab out of the game and max out their gamma so they can somewhat see in the EPIC darkness.

So for the positives if your are lucky enough to not rage quit and you gather up some resources you can tame and house a pet dino. Riding around killing dinos is great fun at each stage of leveling. 
So if you are into self abuse get this title because some day it might be more fun to play for now the game play mostly consist of people waiting until no one in your tribe is online and they come up and glitch your pets through the wall kill them and blow up your door and take all your stuff then they brag about how leet they are and how much raiding they can do. 
All of the “official” servers are set up the same with default vanilla settings which in my opinion leave the game play very lacking. On the other hand many of the other un official servers are so heavily modded and adjusted I once logged into a server where I cut down one single tree and went up 16 levels, at that point you are not even playing the same game every one else is.

So  your only hope might be to pay to play this one on a group server that has some moderation and Guarantees they will not be adding any of the childish mods messing up your game time but that is hit or miss. Good luck and GAME ON

This game had a lengthy early access period on steam, well prior to its official release in Aug 2017.  It's gone through a lot of evolution over the years, and what was once a buggy mess is now... a slightly less buggy mess.  Players and NPCs alike will still fall through the mesh and get stuck in terrain, the pathfinding is still broken, and the AI is still brain dead.  The grind is still real, so real in fact that many players won't be able to vest the time necessary to experience all the content in this game.  And that's a shame.

Because that's about where the negatives end.  These issues, while serious and occasionally frustrating, are not game-breaking.  And they are overshadowed by the plethora of design areas in which this game knocks it out of the park.  

While Ark doesn't feature the tightest gunplay or the most hair-raising combat, it is deep and nuanced in a way that a simple FPS could never be.  The PvE in this game is no slouch, with a handful of 'raid bosses', dungeons to explore, and hundreds of different creature types which have fairly unique combat mechanics.  Meanwhile, the larger scale PvP in this game involves a good amount of strategy, planning, and preparation, and is an absolute spectacle to behold.  

Much of this owes to Ark's graphical fidelity, which remains near best-in-class years after its official release.  The weather effects are superb, with streaks of lightning that crackle across the sky, to sandstorms so thick you can almost taste the sand.  The sound design is incredible as well, leading to a real feeling of immersion that few games can match.  

In Ark, you will level up, allocate stat points, learn better recipes, and make your dps numbers go up just like an MMO.  You'll eventually become powerful enough to go up against enemies that used to one-shot you and come out on top.  But let's be clear - this is not a theme park MMO.  You'll get overconfident.  And then you'll die.  Let's be real, you're going to die a LOT.   And each time it happens, you'll learn what not to do.  You'll learn where you shouldn't go alone.  You'll learn what works, and what doesn't. And you'll get a little better.

The player is always learning because there's always some degree of risk, even on PvE servers.  Feeling safe flying through the trees atop your wyvern?  You just got pounced by a prehistoric rat clinging to that tree, and knocked 50 feet to fall to your death.  Think it's safe because that T-Rex is dead?  Well, those 3 tiny high level troodons in the bush are waiting to knock you out too and make splatter art with your body.  

The sheer quantity of biomes, creatures, craftables, building tools, cosmetics, and activities make this a decidedly non-linear experience.  The dangers of the world aren't hidden behind a level gate, either - they're readily apparent from day one.  You'll either learn to avoid them, or die hideously.  Until one day, tired of getting chased around your spawn by a stubborn carnivore, you'll strap together all your supplies, lay the perfect trap, lay the perfect bait, and land the final hit.  And when it happens, you'll scream into your mic like your team just won the super bowl.  You'll name it after your first dog.  And then, probably a few hours later, it'll wander off and die bc you forgot to put it on neutral or you'll forget to put meat in your feeding trough and it'll starve to death.  Such is Ark.

Each player will make their own adventures, and each player's experience in the Ark will be unique to them.  Oh, did I say Ark?  I meant Arks.  Big, varied maps with multiple biomes, regions, and cave systems.  And you can travel between them fairly easily, especially if you play on a cluster server (which I strongly recommend).

This is among the best survival crafting games on the market, and a big thumbs up *if* you have the time and machine to support it.  If you can commit to the weeks and months long journey through Ark, you'll likely find that the journey itself is an engaging, gorgeous, sometimes terrifying, and supremely worthwhile reward.

This game is incredibly beautiful and a real time-sink. I got the Explorer's Edition in the sale for £20 and I haven't even finished the first island yet - it has been well worth the money. There is masses and masses of content, so many different biomes to explore, a huge array of dinosaurs to meet, avoid and eventually tame. When you start out the game is terrifying - one raptor can easily chew you up and the first spawn point is dangerously close to a Spinosaurus hunting ground. But if you can get to the point where you get a boat then you are a bit safer... then later on you get very good flyers like the Argentavis and the game changes once again into a soaring, exploratory dinosaur-hunt. It is amazing. The only downside is some clipping bugs (dinosaurs falling off ships or getting stuck in buildings) but the game itself and network code is very stable. Oh, and when you get really attached to a favourite dinosaur and it ends up getting eaten by some wandering carnivore. That hurts, but it always feels realistic. Highly recommended, especially if you have a small group of friends to play with or a friendly tribe. Online on your own seems to have the usual griefers to avoid so is not recommended.

Excellent game overall. I have played hundreds of hours and this is the prettiest, most open world, most involving game I have ever played. 

Basically, the game is Minecraft, with DINOSAURS... and obviously amazingly better visuals.

Originally it was glitchy and buggy, but it has come a LONG WAY since early access. They've released this game now for almost every platform, and even have a crappy mobile version. I haven't had any crashes in a LONG time, but there are still "bugs", like for example, you have to restart your dedicated server because your game setting file isn't properly applying, or you can't drink water, etc....

I play on a custom dedicated server with my wife - and recently my 9 and 11 year old kids - and  we just try to survive against the environment. We have about 3 fairly large bases and some good raft bases for getting all the resources we need, and my young kids LOVE taming dinos and hatching babies, which is good because I HATE that part of the game (LOL). The challenge with just a few of us is still more than sufficient. In fact, this game really needs more people in many ways because boss battles and Alpha Dinos are extremely difficult with just a few people. More people also helps speed up resource gathering and base building, and just generally reduces the overall feeling of 'grind' to gather and build.

Getting resources on the game's default settings is very labor and time intensive, and losing even a set of Flak armor can feel a bit frustrating. What is great is that this game allows you to find your own preferences, and really play the way you want.

Turning up the games default resource gathering to insane levels like 200% turns this into a nearly pointless sandbox without challenge, which at that point you may as well use console commands to spawn stuff and just full-on CHEAT... but the default settings on the other hand suck... They are a tedious, GRINDING SLOG. You have to find the middle ground that stays true to all the intended challenges, accomplishments, and elements of the game, while also reducing that grinding tedium.

I recommend  taming set for 3x taming, and resource respawn, gathering, and leveling boosted by 25%. I dialed these perfect settings in right after early access, and now these settings are really close to the official dedicated server settings. In other words even the Ark people figured out that these settings are the way to go, but they don't keep them at the perfect settings, oddly. A few times a year, they do "special events" where they do 3x taming and resource boosts. They are trying to lure players to the servers this way, and they know that this is just BETTER. So they leave the settings at "OK - but not great" most of the year, and make Alpha Tribes grind away, and then fix the settings once in awhile. This is why I recommend SKIP the official servers, and just make your own server where you can fix your own settings. 

I also made night 75% shorter because night sucks and leaves you cursing for daylight.

I made my own server for this game. It runs at least 3.2 Gbs of RAM and will spike and increase until the server will run 10-12 Gbs of RAM!!! I installed the server on an intel NUC that I bought a few years back. It has a Core-i3 (6th gen) with 16Gb of RAM (a $400 machine built mostly just for an Ark Server)  

There are lots of guides online on how to make an ark server. If you follow the guides, you can easily create a server that your friends can connect to, but there is a trick to getting friends from outside your home to see your server. For some reason even after doing everything right, setting windows firewall to allow the server traffic, and properly doing the port-forwarding on your home router... almost 100% guaranteed your server will NOT show up  -ever - in the unofficial server lists in ARK. The secret is going to a 3rd party website to find your ARK server over the WAN.   

https://www.battlemetrics.com/servers/ark

just search for the name of your server and you will find it if you did everything correctly, and then your friends can join you on your very own server, and you don't have to pay for anything extra! 

Having a static IP would be helpful so your buddies don't get booted when your ISP renews your IP and it changes, but I find it is not 100% necessary as they can always reconnect. If you want to call your ISP and see if they can give you a static IP for like an extra $10.00/ month, hopefully... that is a good thing if you actually have friends elsewhere who would play. Still much cheaper than paying for a hosted server.

That's pretty much it. Have fun. It's a solid way to waste time.

-Dinosaurs immediately losing the ability to path correctly after being tamed
-Cave Mechanics (Mainly grappling hooks not enabled on all servers)
-Everything takes FOREVER to do (Breeding intervals, Egg hatching, raising baby dinos...)

So let me start by saying this game has the potential to be a lot of fun, but due to the constant rubber-banding on servers and constant lag spikes it becomes extremely frustrating. One of the worst mechanics in the game is trying to do caving if your server does not allow grappling hooks, not being able to use flying dinosaurs in caves in understandable, but the grappling hook being up to the individual servers. How am I supposed to jump around on tiny ledges above lava with a dinosaur when I am almost constantly being moved back several feet anytime I jump?? It adds so much unnecessary difficulty/game mechanics that really add nothing to the game. Every dinosaur seems to collide with any bit of environment that is even remotely in its path.

Overall I would say get it if you want to goof around with friends while riding and fighting dinosaurs, don't get it if you are looking for a game to actually try and progress in without a bunch of unnecessary content between you and the endgame.

[h1]4.5/10 - Bad, but still somewhat playable.[/h1]

[h1]I have never seen so many amazing ideas mixed in with so many bad ones.   [/h1]
This is the most difficult, non-beginner friendly game I have ever played.   I LOVE hard games.    This one might be overdoing it on the difficulty.    I felt dirty making my own map and change the difficulty to my preferred settings.   (Sorry, but I don't feel like grinding for 100 hours just to get an "ok" item.)   I even had people helping me out on multiplayer, but I was still getting my butt wooped.    

[h1]Permadeath + hundreds of bugs don't go well together[/h1]
I took a screen shot of every bug I ran into while playing this game and I have a lot of screenshots....

You lose all your items and gear when your die.   You can collect your gear off your body, but the problem is that you and your dinosaurs will get stuck.... a lot.    I fell into a hole and couldn't get out.   Sometimes it will be impossible to retrive your items.   I built a ladder right in front of my face, but I couldn't climb it.  You have to wait and starve to death so you can respawn.   Their maps are full of these holes too.   This reason alone is enough to not recommend the game.   

[h1]Positive points of ARK[/h1]
It is hard to find positive things to say.....   The game looks great.   The dinosaurs look awesome, especially on the Aberation map.  You can change the settings on your own private games/servers.  This helps you avoid waiting insainly long wait times and avoids the need to grind for hundreds of hours.   There are so many things to create, that you will not want to craft everything.  

[h1]Not new player friendly[/h1]
The real issue behind this game, is that new players get thrown into the fire and will often fight high level enemies in the "easy" zone.    It will get easier when you get better gear, but It is painful for new players to grind through the beginning.  You run extremely slow when starting a new character and you cannot outrun raptors that are trying to eat you.   The real name should be Ark - Prepare To Die.

[H1] You can die within 5 seconds of spawning.  [/h1]
This game has so many good ideas, but it also has so many things wrong with it.    Like the 2nd map for example.   Did the developers even play the map "scorched earth" as a new rookie?!?!    I can die of heat stroke within 110 seconds of spawning.    Once again, I love hard games, but their default difficulty might be a little overkill.    They need to make starting zones more beginner friendly.

[h1]Complicated pet commands[/h1]
It is extremely painful for new players to figure out how to control their pets.   I wasted a lot of time, effort and pets as I was trying to master the pet whistles.

[h1]Lots of things in this game do not make sense[/h1]
Google will be your best friend while trying to figure out this game.  Air conditioners do not function like you would expect.  (You can die of heat stroke right next to a bunch of working air conditioners?!?)   Alpha dinosaurs and wild drakes cannot be knocked out or tamed.   Grindstones will continue to craft items for you, even if you walk away from it.   It just doesn't make sense and you might have to figure out things the hard way.

[h1]Terrible map tools[/h1]
The worst, most awful part about this game is the map tool.   It sucks to retrieve your items off your dead body.  Combine this with bugs and your body can be impossible to find, let alone retrieve.    I like the idea of keeping it simulated like it is a real hand drawn map, but it isn't worth the pain of having such a terrible, TERRIBLE tool. 

[h1]Horrific status icons[/h1]
While playing the game, you will get status symbols that show if you are hot or cold.   The problem is that half of them don't make sense.   "This status symbol looks like a wolf howling at the moon.   What is that supposed to mean!?!?"   (search on google)   "Oh, that is actually a man, wiping his forehead because it is hot...."   Be prepared to google these effect a lot.  

[h1]Review verdict[/h1]
[h1]4.5/10 - Bad, but still somewhat playable.[/h1]
Insanely difficult survival games are my favorite type of video games to play, yet I still struggle to recommend ARK.   I could recommend it, but you must be ok with permadeath and getting stuck in holes all the time.  You must be ok with running into bugs, like getting your dinosaurs trapped in someone else's base.  You will not be able to get your dinosaur out without the help of the base owner (if they are even online).   You must like crazy hard survival games.   Most people are not ok with these things, so I do NOT recommend this game.  This game obviously has so much potential, but it is PLAGUED with so many awful problems.

I will say I have not played since "official" release but I have had some great times in this game. I played on a private servers with friends that brought their friends and it became large for a while. Tons of fun literally couldn't wait to get home to play. 

At the same time I bought this game for something like 12-15 bucks on a sale and if it were still priced like that I'd leave a good review but considering they've raised the price to 60. Kind of absurd. Granted if the bugs and other issues had been fixed then ok maybe. But the bugs were never really addressed while I played. Talking to friends that still play say they still experience the same stupid stuff I did as before. Falling through certain areas, clipping into terrain. Just all around wonky physics I suppose. Given the experiences I've had I would say yes to a 20-30 dollar game. Buy it, you wouldn't regret it but 60 dollars? Better off finding something else sadly. 

If you do not heed the many users that feel the same way I do then bite the bullet and get a private server for you and some mates.

ARK: Survival Evolved was one of the most entertaining games for a long time in my case as lack of content was never an issue. Comparing the current price with late 2015 I'd say it is more so on the expensive side. The learning curve is very high similar to other survival games and playing can feel fairly unrewarding especially for newer players.


As for gameplay ARK: Survival Evolved is mainly focused on the player versus environment scenario with the player versus player mode as an added bonus. If competing against others in a highly unbalanced game is just not your thing, there's plenty more stuff to sink thousands of hours into. Mastering the taming system with over 190 unique creatures available can be quite enjoyable for some people and exploring & experiencing each map provided by the DLCs can be quite fun for others.


If you're someone like me and decide to spend thousands of hours in-game replayability can play a big role in your experience too. I can almost guarantee every time you start over there's something new to accomplish be it building a larger base or finding that one tribe you've fought against last wipe. 


All in all the ARK: Survival Evolved is a great game and I'd suggest getting it if it does look appealing to you, and if you're wondering what's my overall opinion on it, after more than a few years of playing I'd rate it a 8.5 out of 10.

Well I have a lot of hours on the game. So its not bad. 

Pros:
Game has fun mechanics to it. Always keeping you busy. Plenty of dinos to choose from. Level up system is enjoyable. Huge selection of mods to use.  Lots of things to craft. Graphics are alright. Huge and interesting maps. Taming dinos is fun..As long as you don't get them killed. Many ways to play like, base building, pvp, hunter, fishing, breeding and, exploring.

Cons:
You might as well buy a private server otherwise, you will spent 12 real hours taming a level 80 bronto. You need friends for this game or you will not have as much fun. It is a chore to have to keep feeding dinos and replenish your spoiling food/resources. You have to play every day in order to keep these things going. Anything could destroy your base deleting hours of work in mere seconds. I've also had janky issues with throw spears and arrows at flying dinos not doing damage, even if there sticky in dinos head.

I have played quite alot of hours on this game, and honestly, I can't recommend it, I really want to, but I just can't, it is such a good game but is let down by alot of basic quality of life features that force me to not recommend this.

The main example is stuff falling through the map, including your characters dead bodies, this mainly happens in caves, and happens alot in caves.  This is a glitch that should not have made it out of early release but not only was in the full release but still exists.  People have been even known to lose dinosaurs because they fall through the map. Luckily this is solved by downloading a gravestone mod so all your items is stored in a nice neat gravestone that just so happens as not to fall through the floor.

Another issue is the building, due to the way foundations work in this game, it constricts building alot unless you have perfectly flat land, this is because the foundations cannot be stacked.  The building is constricting in other ways too, but that is just the most restricting.

There is also a problem with non-dedicated sessions, which is incredibly annoying when playing with friends.  There is a limited range in which the non-host players can travel away from the host.  Now, whilst this can be changed in the setting before you start the game, it is still incredibly limited.  When in a non-dedicated session you always have to keep an eye eachother so as to not wander too far off.  This is easy for the non-host to do as you can see the hosts player tag for miles, but for the host, the other players name when you look in the specific direction and even then it's difficult to see.

There were a few other issues that I cannot name off the top of my head right now, but it's basic stuff that holds the game back and has caused me alot of stress and anger, which therefore stops me from recommending it.

So I have played a bit over a thousand hours of this game. It has the potential to be amazing, but it never will be. They are on expansion 8 or something, and still have bugs that are from the release. Today was a bit of a breaking point. I have been mudding around in the toxic PVP and decide that its time to down a boss, and work on PVE.  My partner and I breed all the dinos we need and head to the ob. Attempt one, only 9 of our 20 dinos get in. All 20 were in range before hand. NBD it was a glitch, that kinda stuff happens. Attempt two, all dinos are in, and the boss despawns 5 minutes into the fight. We are kicked out and lose our reagents to summon the boss. After this we speak with other who say this is common. How can you have  bug this large and just not fix it. It takes days of time to get a survivor leveled up and supplied enough to attempt a boss, and then it just despawns and takes your stuff. Waste of money, and I got it on sale. This game is the biggest tease and disappointment. Don't pour hours of your life into a game that will just bug out and throw it away. Stay clear of this unfinished product.    

Also this company really needs to invest in some moderators. There are threats of death, rape, and everything else. Its just common place, and I don't see any way to report anything.

This game is such a great concept and my tribe has had a lot of fun playing it. HOWEVER... if you are thinking of purchasing this for the PvP aspect, don't waste your money. This game is a major time sync and the dev's have had over 5 years to solve the absolute worst issues with this game. Meshing and Aimbotting. 

Everytime you go on a raid as a mid-high level tribe, you have to 100% account for the fact that some brand new character level 73, will show up with a fab rifle and continue to kill everyone in your tribe. Larger tribes have programs that they pay around $500/month just so they can aimbot and avoid detection from ARK's anti cheat. Your only hope is that you put in a ticket and a GM shows up before you've had to pack up and leave. 

And what's worse, the person aimbotting generally finds out what server you are from and tells you he's going to mesh your base (blow it up from inside the map textures) There are new methods to do this found almost weekly and while yes they eventually get patched, Wildcard cannot keep up with the new methods that are being found. So no matter what you do you have to assume there are cheaters in every tribe.

Months of grinding every day and raising dinos just to be shot by some kid paying a monthly subscription to cheat and losing your entire base to some guy under the map. Even though Wildcard tries to ban the accounts that are cheating, the problem is people have ways to buy new accounts for pennies on the dollar and to them it's worth a few bucks to destroy everything you have. Don't buy this game for PvP

Unpopular opinion, but this is the 2nd best game I’ve ever played. I am not going to talk about its issues because they're not hard to find. Mostly people who play this game and complain don't realize the game is built for mega-tribes or servers with 100x rates. The game is grindy and you won’t experience its full potential without a team. This is the only game I’ve played that appeals to everyone. On offical you can have pve stay at home moms that play and only raise cute dinos and you can also have the hard-core csgo guys that are insane at pvp. It's also the only game with basically infinite replay value. I see people complain about the game with 1k+ hours and i always think at least you got your moneys worth from the game. After i quit i have never been able to get even 200+ hours on a game since no game really has the strong social aspect ark does (evee online maybe). Anyways I definitely recommend trying it as long as you can get into a mega-tribe, you will definitely make some friends along the way, the guy who build my first gaming PC i actually met on this game so. Just don’t get addicted; know when to stop would be my only warning.

After now about 13.000 hours of total playtime, over all of my accounts. I can safely give a honest review of Ark Survival Evolved. I`ve started playing this game almost right after launch and I was quickly immersed in the amazing Idea of surviving on an Island filled with prehistoric creautures and the amazing scenarios it was giving me. With every update it became better in graphics, gameplay mechanics and accossiatelly some  new creatures that made the game more broad. Until Scorched Earth arrived and everyone was quick to jump on the "Why does this game have a paid Dlc if it´s still in early access" train. But I must say that I loved Scorched, regardless of the need for a dlc at that point. It improved everything I liked about the Base Game. The new Creatures were amazing and the map was honestly beautiful. Aswell as that it brought a lot of new gameplay mechanics and opportunitys. When Aberration hit us, it was in my oppinion the best state Ark has  ever been. Almost everybody loved it.  It was filled with great ideas that were well executed. Aswell as that it was full of great story elements that were leaving us all excited for Extinction. Extinction is where it kinda fell a bit apart for me. Wildcard had amazing ideas for Extinction, that they teased to us in charity streams before it launched and it sounded really interesting. I for one couldn´t wait for the new Titans that rommed the biomes and the mutated corrupted creatures that we would need to protect orbital supply drops from. But when it launched it wasn`t at all what we expected. Some great ideas where scrapped and replaced by mechanics that already existed, like titans needing to be spawned in terminal, when they were suppossed to be in the biomes all the time. Don´t get me wrong I still enjoyed Extinction, interms of story and gameplay, but it didnt live up to the potential that it had as the apparent "Last Dlc". In my opinion though wildcard should have left the story after Extinction. It had a great epic finale. That left me, who is very deeply invested and interested in the story, satisfied and didn´t have the need to be continued or expanded. And then we got Genesis Part 1. Genesis had kind of the same problems like Extinction for me, but much much worse. They kept telling us that it would be a "whole new experience" and that its gonna be "nothing like we have seen before". But when it finally launched all the new mechanics that were supposed to be interesting new gameplay assets, like Biome teleportation and the new mission system, aswell as the Hexagon Exchange were all to unbalanced or straight up broken like the new taming methods. The new creatures we got were great, but the Ferox or Bloodstalker for example were way to op for how easy you could get them. Another Problem was that we had 12 new creatures in both Scorched and Aberration, 11 in Extincion, but on Genesis we only got 5 new tameable creatures and less items than usual. I find that kind of lack luster for a Dlc you can only buy in a Season Pass. At the core I know what route they were wanting to go with the Genesis Simulation story wise and the new gameplay aspects, but they didn`t think some things through to the end. In my opinion. Overall I think Ark is a pretty good game at the moment, of course its flowed, but you can still have lots of fun with it and get easily immersed in the gigantic variation of creatures, environment and the overarching story. But with Genesis as the newest example it kinda showes that Wildcard isnt really putting in as much love and effort into their Dlcs as they used to do. It kinda comes foreward as if they only make new dlcs to squeeze as much money as possible out of the rapidly decreasing Fanbase, before the game finally dies because of countlles bugs ,that get fixed way to late  , lack of Tlc and lack of interest in new Dlc. They really should focus more on improving the  base game  before they make more dlcs or add new free maps. Island for example hadn´t gotten any improvement since the launch of the game. Some new Biomes were added,but about 50% the map is still the same and Island is still the map most new players start playing on. With Genesis Part 2 on the horizon I really hope wildcard give themselves the needed amount of time to do better and improve. They can realease it in 2022 for all that i care, but they need to make something great for their "Last Dlc" or Arks Fanbase will most probably slowly die out and Ark Survival Evolved will forever be remembered as a bad game with great potential.

No, at least not on online servers:
- too much lag,too many "déjà vu"s (Everything stops up to 10 seconds, avatar will be 'teleported' back in time)
- erver often gets reset/rolled back to some previous timepoint/day
- server is often down for about an hour or more (days)
- server ID changed - try to find it!
- even diconnected inside your base you can and will be killed (Raptor, drown??)  (PvE Server!!!)
- storage boxes are emptied after you reconnect (despite being inside your base) (PvE Server!!!)
- you got time to play: sorry, must wait for update (1/2 hour is no exception, maybe better with SSD)
- oher player's dinos somehow end up stuck inside your base, even if closed
- first connection attempt most often ends with Connection timeout after 3-5 Minutes
- once connected, if you are lucky, you get a message that the server will shutdown in 5 minutes, or, more it just crahes (and stays offline for another 1/2 hour or longer)
- server back online, great, but all the bad guys you have killed will respawn and probably eat you
- walking/jumping over rocks, you or your dinos risk being stuck - and you must wait until you starve since somehow the client thinks you are falling, so you can't  do anything to die faster  (eating or punching, ...)
- don't take vacations without internet and laptop - everything will be dead/removed after some short time
- small client update (almost every week - released?) was about 1 1/2 hour to download and install (more than additional 30GB of free disk while updating)

Jun 2019:
Geting worse and worse: last update reports: "TIME REMAINING more than 1 year" -  long time to update!

Single player only on a better machine!
And do not believe the minimal requirements - it is using about 120GB - even more is needed to install compulsory updates (often 40GB additional free disk space to download and install)!

Jun. 2020:
- updates every week, some will reset your settings, other your stats,...
- taming for over an hour (even more clearing the area), server restart without warning, bad creatures spawn exactly over you and attack your tame
- after last update the official server just stopped running, for days and still no notice or advice...
Aug. 2020:
- wanted to check the game - just after loging in  "server will be restarted in 5 minutes" (+ 1/2 hour to restart client and connect (if no update needed))

Despite my quite sizable number of hours put into this game, I always play single player to avoid PvP and raiding etc. I want my buildings unmolested, and my head nice and without sniper rifle holes. Since I'm the only one of my friends who owns the game I play solo. After hours and hours of playing like a scared rabbit, hiding in my little corner of safety to harvest and craft, I decide to try my hand at taming a raptor, or venturing into the nearby unknown with my tamed dilophosaurs... even with settings ENGINEERED for the single player experience, I am immediately put back in my place and my tamed dinos are slain.

I LOVE dinosaurs, and thirst for good fun dinosaur vidya games, but I have to give this one a pass. Too hard for the type of player I am, (again, even after taking a baseball bat to the games kneecaps with difficulty, tame speed, harvest rate, player health, etc). I really doubt I'll ever boot this game up again, which is a damn shame since it has an awesome concept and simply BEAUTIFUL graphics. But if I wanna walk a short ways from my camp and get one shotted from inside my house by a spinosaur I'll play Primal Carnage. That game at least is fun.

I used to always get so frustrated with this game for continuing to dump new content without ever improving the base game ever since I started attempting to play back in 2016 on a laptop clearly incapable of gaming. My inability to run this game on the lowest graphics setting was always a turn off for me and started to create a very biased opinion on the quality of the game itself.

As you can probably tell by the hours I have managed to dump into this game, I finally got a gaming PC of my own. My largest complaint about the game has soon become one of my favorite things about the entire experience. The TLC updates that continue to improve old dinos and community driven improvements on a regular basis have aided greatly in building my enthusiasm for what this game will be years from now when I continue to log on and enjoy a survival game that, at its core, boasts some of the best PvE experiences I have endured to date.

Ark. I play it a lot. Probably will keep doing so. Do I enjoy this game? Maybe I did at one point. They keep upping the rates which is cool. 

The bugs make me want to rip out my own eyes because even on pve its really player vs enviroment, lag, and bugs. Lets not even mention the server resets/slash saves they may or may not teleport you, your dinos, or wild dinos to undesirable locations.

And the Best(Biggest). The time sink. Even with the upped rates, it still take 3 days to raise a decent dinosaur, and i'm talking cool shit, not raptors and dilphs, I'm talking ice breathing lizard cats and spiderman symbiote spiders.
and three days might not be so bad, if it wasn't for the fact that you gottta sit there for five hours and watch it or it will starve to death. Don't even get me started on otters.

This game is a time sink, that will keep you in it because you've spent so much time there. I guess you could play it single player and up rates to ungodly levels to maker game bearable, or shell out a about twenty bucks a month for a private server for your friends. 

Look at you library. Do you have unplayed games? Cause this game will try to never let you play them again, that is unless you wanna be shitting yourself on a beach forever in Ark. 

TLDR; Do i like this game? Sometimes.

Would I RECOMMEND this game? Only if you hate yourself, and want to get stressed out by games too.

This game is terrible in every aspect, it's grindy, not rewarding, glitchy almost to unplayable state, very annoying, and very unfair.

I originally wrote this review in language i use back in 2018/2019, so the review is accurate to that date

Back then i used to play non-dedicated with some fella of mine, we both experienced how terrible this game is, i have no idea if they patched some or even any of the glitches, but the most memorable one for me was the character getting stuck in literally every piece of enviorment, the reason the character was getting stuck is unknown, but it happened when you go over a sharp edge/corner of the object

The unfairness of the game was on every step, the game gave you ABSOLUTELY no clues about where you have to progress, and tought "hey you are new here right? let's spawn some alpha raptors in your area", in the region which was noted as "easy"

Entire map is one large maze, if you are playing this game blindly, then you should know what i mean, the only way to complete the game before you die from boredom is to look up wiki cave locations, better yet the caves were so broken in previous versions the game would render the cave for even 10 minutes, sometimes the game even crashed for me

The "dragging to the host" system in non-dedicated server makes absolutely no sense and is just pure frustration factory, if you will tell me the reason is to prevent host from crashing/overloading pc due to massive area loading due to players spreading across the map, let me remind you this game weights F***ING 120 GIGABYTES, anyways what it does is basically it drags any player which is not host to the host with unknown force if they get "too far" away from the host, this can even kill you if you get pulled against the wall. You can change that in game settings but i noticed it after long time, the effect still works if you load a new area like cave or even volcano peak and there's no proper way to remove it

The way how the game requires you to grind is awful, let's say you wanna craft a pistol, guess what, you need (around) 65 IRON BARS FOR A F***ING PISTOL, but you can't yet, why? you need to level up to level 30-40 (not sure on which you unlock the pistol), you get averagely 5 iron from one vein, the problem is the veins are EXTREMLY rare compared to normal rocks (you can get iron from normal rocks/boulders but it's super rare), you finally achieve the iron bars and level/blueprint for the pistol, you craft it, then you wanna test it out - craft bullets, 5 hours of mining or rather searching for iron veins, you get to craft your first bullet, you go test it out, it broke after 20 shots, guess what, you need more metal to repair it! to make you even more angry, you can mine metal "FOR SOME REASON" from rocks that are on beaches, game gives you no hints for that, no clue, yet they are common and very easy to find

So how is the game frustrating? well thirdly tame a dinosaur for 5 hours, secondly put it to sleep with 100 tranqualizer arrows/darts, and firstly grind for god knows how long for the materials, go into combat, get SOMEHOW killed from it's back, and praise that it doesn't die and you arrive there on time because you forgot to disable "passive mode", you arrive there, your dinosaur is barely alive, you want to get to it, but you get deathcammed by a raptor which is COMPLETLY unavoidable, you die, your dino aswell, you quit, move the game onto a movable drive SOMEHOW WITH 120 GIGABYTES, you cut the drive into pieces, burn it, store in potato sack, drown it in the deepest part of the ocean, but you realise you need 500 iron ingots for a boat, also don't do the same for me if you find yourself disagreeing with this review, it's mainly my personal opinion

TL;DR don't buy it, it's a waste of money, sanity, family, neighbours, friends and life

I don't have nearly as many hours as most of the other reviewers on here, but I believe that I've played this game enough to be able to review it. I've been with this game for quite some time, checking in on the progress every once in a while, and I have to say I'm disappointed in where this game has ended up. The UI has always been horrible, to the point where trying to find anything at all is a pain. Interacting with dinosaurs shouldn't be so time consuming if all it involves is menus. The number of dinosaurs is impressive and the amount of locations and the size of the worlds is incredible. I just can't seem to stick around for longer than thirty levels, and I'm not sure what it is that prevents me from doing so. It is probably a culmination of the glitches, the weird mix of high level dinosaurs in low level areas, the player base not in check. I love playing with friends in private servers, but it is such a pain to set up that it's almost not even worth it. I dislike that they have focused on additions and dlc rather than repairing and streamlining gameplay. I just think the developers could have done more with the base game before going out of their way to add so much content that doesn't even make the game better. I will say that the amount of time I have played with friends, and the amount of entertainment I've received from it nets it a positive review, but it really is an iffy positive. I look forward to seeing what they end up doing with it, though.

Having put almost 1400 hours into this game, and having played since early beta, ARK will forever be one of my favorite games.  It's got a ton of great expansions, lots of different maps to play on, and the game itself is just so much fun.  The creators are constantly optimizing the game and adding new content to look forward too.  ARK was one of the first survival games I played when I first started PC gaming, and it will always hold a special place in my heart.  I have a bunch of friends who also have the game, and we've all spent hours upon hours playing together, taming Dinos, and building the coolest projects.  There's a ton of great add-on content out there for ARK too, but the standalone game is still great by itself.  The game play overall is definitely more fun when played with friends, but you can still enjoy your time in ARK if playing solo too.

I personally found this game very realistic or to say "living the life" like. Please take a seat and let me explain my findings and remarks from my humble experience... At the beginning you are thrown naked, afraid and beefed up like Belgian blue bull to this seemly beautiful world with stunning scenery, nice peaceful dinos and other beefed up fellow studs which whom you just cant wait to knock a few beers up, watch sunset and touch yourself at night with each other. However reality is often disappointing as in real life...  When I spawned, I started to walk down the beach while carefully examining my perfectly trimmed nails and muscular forearms. Sun was brightly shinning on my exquisite figure, I felt like on a verge of best day of my life. Then it all changes... Suddenly I felt a very dull and strong force upon the back of my head, right after that a very putrid and foul stench reached my nostrils. I turned my head to see what monstrosity produced this unworldly substance. Oh... the scenery I will never forget... A group of overgrown monkeys were stampeding in my direction and throwing their shit on me. Immediately after I turned, I received a huge load of warm shit in my eyes and on my nose. I started to run towards the sea to clean my face and neck, at this time monkeys were already near me. When I reached the nearest body of water I profoundly started to wash my eyes while monkeys proceeded to pummel my body.. then I realised the shit is not going away... Instead of washing, I was drinking the water with E keyboard key while shit was still obstructing my vision and the pummeling monkeys kept renewing the shit on my face with fresh layer of their waste. Not more than a few second later I died in vain while monkeys were presenting their alpha posture over my mangled entrails full of water and shit. Anyhow... such scenarios are inevitable at the beginning but you will experience them less and less often when progressing through the game progress and levels, eventually you will become the one who penetrates their ovaries and spill all kinds of your and theirs bodily fluids. Unlike in the real world, after some time and work you will become what you want, build your self a house, tame some posh dinos, be self reliable, have fun.

Totally recommend this game, its like irl but you can actually become something.

This is a game that depends on if you want to put the time in. This game is ruthless at times, and will show no mercy ever. However, ask yourself this; how many other games allow you to fire laser beams from the back of a TRex? How many games let you fly on the back of Pterodactyls? How many games let you have a Brontosaurus carry your lumber resources back to your home base? This is the game that, if you let yourself enjoy what it has to offer, and push on through past all of the challenges, it is SO WORTH IT! While you will definitely need to put in the time, the reward is one of the most immersive and realistic dinosaur survival games of all time. It offers intense challenges and worthy rewards, allows you to explore how a survival game that does not hold your hand feels like, and if you were to get into the dlc maps, my god, it is incredible. Very few games can do what ARK does and not require mods. ARK requires a very specific set of interests to draw people in, but it does its job well.

And for all of you people complaining about offline raiding, you do realise there is an option, right front and centre, that determines if you want offline raiding or not. It doesn't reduce offline raiding, it completely removes it altogether! The only reason you would have that on is if you enjoy offline raids. How many of us do? (If you guessed none, you are right on the money)

I’ve put off writing a proper review for ARK for a long time because I knew I wouldn’t be able to do it justice and I’ll probably edit this multiple times but anyways, here it goes.

First off, ARK is hands down my favorite game ever and no other game has even come close. It is just such a unique game that is brimming with content. I mean what other game can you ride a T-rex or build a house on a giant flying pterosaur or use a giant crab to hop around an extensive cave system or use  a moth to steal eggs from dragons or go wyvern surfing or fight King-Kong with an army of dinosaurs or zip through space with a blood sucking spider or get abducted by a freaky little crocodile or support a gremlin’s drug addiction or decimate a bug infested cave with a sloth or fight Kaiju with giant robots, the list goes on. There are so many combinations and ways to play this game that it effectively lasts forever. Sure some methods are more effective and practical than others but for instance you could use what’s essentially a turkey to complete one of the hardest achievements in the game. And as the game continues to progress, more items and creatures are added that multiply out the possibilities for goals old and new. ARK does an amazing job at rewarding player’s achievements because nothing can compare to the moment you tame and ride your first dinosaur. At the beginning of the game you are just a weak human getting killed over and over by things as simple as ants but by the end you are the strongest force on the map with a super suit and an army of creatures capable of taking down even the strongest foes.But, there is a lot of value to being a noob in ARK because one day you’ll cherish the memories of when you didn’t know that eating those black berries put you to sleep or scrounging for those same berries to keep that pesky spino’s torpor up. That’s another thing, you’ll make lots of memories in ARK as you try to figure out how to survive. There are very few games that I remember like ARK because most others just blend together into the same with each match turning out just like the last, whilst every playthrough of ARK is unique and captivating. The only downside of ARK is that the other games you play will pale in comparison. I haven’t found another game that gets the recipe quite right and I doubt I ever will. I wish the future survivors of ARK good luck as they embark on a journey like no other. Keep it snappy!

Ark is a great game for anyone who loves dinosaurs AND science fiction. 

However, it's very difficult to run (I blame that on the engine), it takes a very long time to install, and it's riddled with bugs. For example, if you exit a server on a dinosaur or without standing on a platform, your body can fall through the world, rendering you unable to get back whatever (sometimes expensive) gear you had. I wish the developers would focus more on updating the building mechanics, adding new structure items, and fixing problems, rather than making new DLCs. 

However, it's still fun once you get past the rage inducing bugs. I have lots of fond memories of this game.

Okay, so I am daring to recommend this game but there are some caveats with that recommendation.

First of all, you'll probably be better off waiting until the game goes on sale and picking it up then. The game is quite buggy as the Devs seem to favor adding new content over making the game actually work. I will also note that not messing with the game settings and playing the game single player is just asking to have an awful time. If you mess with the game settings though, and have a friend or two to play with, it is a mostly enjoyable experience.

Don't get me wrong, the game will absolutely spit in your face and stomp on your long dead corpse like the bastard that it is. I've recently been playing a game with friends and we had to move out of the area that we had lived in because the game just kept spawning packs of Alpha T-Rexes everywhere which were just absolutely demolishing everything and everyone.

If you are looking for a fun, casual, balanced, and fair survival game experience, then skip this game and play some Minecraft. This game is clusterfuck of broken shit and almost malicious game design. But once again, if you play the game with friends and with settings like XP and Taming Speed turned up a bit you'll still probably get some meaningful fun out of it.

SO FUN, but not very beginner friendly. Wish there was a better fleshed out tutorial... would have gone a long way with player retention I think.

A few weeks later: Avoid. Object containers (or "hitboxes") are unfinished and massive, while pathing is questionable at best. This results in objects getting stuck on all kinds of things, resulting in bugs and glitches like crazy. For example, try running through the forest with a pack of dinos following you. You'll lose most of them to simple rocks and trees. Hatch too many babies at once to close to each other? Say hello to your useless, bugged, 3-headed carno. Give up on traveling by land and go all argentavis in the skies? Guess what, they get stuck on trees too.

Beautiful game, but it feels like it was made with minecraft level object containers. What a travesty. It feels closer to an alpha state game with the current frequency of bugs.

I'll admit to having quite a bit of fun too. But I'm not sure if it was outweighed by the time spent dealing with bugs and grinding. So close to being a great game. If the devs ever reworked object containers, I'd be back on in a heartbeat.

ARK...Oh ARK... It's times like this I wish we had a  neutral review option instead of a purely negative or positive review option.
But since we have only two, I'll lean more into Do Not Purchase ARK For Fifty Dollars.

The fact the developers think this is a fair price for the game in its current state is beyond maddening, it shouldn't have even left Early Access yet with the amount of issues it has still going. As much as I love this game and  would love to tell you to play it, I just can't for its price. 

Bugs are a constant issue you will run into, where AI fails to do as its supposed to, or strange random deaths just dive bomb you and your dinosaurs because..I don't know, you stepped wrong? The fact that the only times it was actually fully playable was with the use of several mods tells a story in-of-itself of the mechanics and balancing issues this game has had since the day I bought it.

Is it fun? At times.
Is it pretty? Oh definitely.
Is it optimized? 25-30 minute load times and random lag even with the best of computers? No. Go back and try again.

It's a sham that they decided to sell an unbalanced product for the price of a full game, while demanding $20 for DLCs as well without even bothering to comb over the most basic of optimization issues. The game is HUGE due to a lack of paying attention to how to deal with its struggles.

Every Dinosaur generated (This can be...hundreds depending on the map) spawns in at once, and moves around despite not being close to the player character. On a server, that can handle that, fine. But in Single player, not having things pause or despawn when not in use is foolish beyond belief. There is a rampant issue with Caves in particular that I'm not sure ever got fixed.

So a cave can be accessed, and then the floor becomes walkable for players and dinosaurs, and the cave derenders when not in use. That's good. However. Dinosaurs have still spawned because every.single.dinosaur on the map spawns in at once. What does this mean when you enter a cave? There's no creatures. Because they fell through the floor that wasn't there. This is a single player issue due to servers always having everything loaded.

Do I love  breeding and catching dinosaurs and creatures? Definitely!
Is building fun? ...Sometimes.
Is it gorgeous and fun to explore the maps? Yeah!
Is there a lot of content? Tons.
Is it worth $60 + DLC costs? No.
Is it worth picking up with the apparent flaws? Maybe for $15 like when I first bought it.

Improvements to mechanics, balancing, and optimization are slow, and often "improvements" break core mechanics that weren't even the real issue.

I love you ARK, but...Get it together.

updated-

PROs:
+ Level design is very good, Aberration, Extinction, Genesis especially.
+ Graphics and textures for *most* stuff are very well done
+ Concept and lore is interesting
+ Group play is a lot of fun
+ Good PVE content.
+ Variety of items which have lots of cool features (greenhouse, grapling hooks, etc)
+ Hunting down animals to tame makes for a fun gameplay loop
+ Recent updates and features have alleviated a few of my main complaints about the game and made it more approachable.

CONs:
- Avoid PVP servers at all costs. This game is a major time investment and PVP servers will continually wipe you. Offline base raiding with easily obtained materials, cheaters, gankers, etc. It's simply not worth spending hundreds of hours building anything of value on a PVP server unless maybe you're in a megatribe or something. 

- Character Models and player-structures still look like garbage. They have time to make a bunch of new expansions with pretty maps and cool animals- but then they leave the most visually-frequent assets looking like trash.

- Building is overall *really* bad compared to any other game in the genre, even much older ones. It's very frustrating to create an aesthetically-pleasing base without mods. The building mods which have been out for several years now are substantially better than the base game and continue to make the official team look like idiots.

- Weird idiot design decisions- like caves, which require a high level animal to clear, are too small for those animals to fit into, except with a cryopod and a lot of patience.

- It's been out for several years and they still haven't fixed their horrible-ass hitboxes. half or more of my pve-related wipes are solely due to their shit hitboxes sticking together; making it impossible to disengage from an unwinnable fight. enemies pretty much stick to you like they're coated in superglue and make it impossible to move until you die. (Animal's tails, wings, etc all clip you and get you stuck everywhere. They basically just said visual mesh = collision mesh like lazy amateurs.)

____________________________________

 
This game can be fun in a group on PVE or private servers with mods that potentially solve the games core failures. With recent changes in official server rates and Genesis patches coming out it could be worth getting back into.

Waking up in Ark: Survival Evolved is a bit of a jolt. Lost and naked, new players open their eyes on the shore of an island teeming with dinosaurs and a wild, hostile ecosystem. Ark is an open world in the truest sense: there's nowhere I need to go, nowhere I'm supposed to be. But I can't just starve to death on that beach, so I set off.

More than two years after it emerged as (yet another) open-world survival hit, Ark has finally launched. We're still learning how customer-funded, Early Access development affects games, but for Ark the flush of money and attention seems to have led to an unbalanced game with too many extraneous features and unrefined, unfocused fundamentals.
